TranslitTitle   = Yume e mukatte gō! Satoshi to Gō!!
NativeTitle     = 夢へ向かってゴー！サトシとゴウ！！

ShortSummary    = Today is Pokemon Orientation Day at the Sakuragi Institute! The six visiting children are split into three teams: Team Blue escorted by Satoshi and Pikachu; Team Red by Go, Rabbifuto and Koharu; and Team Yellow by Professor Sakuragi and Koharu's Wanpachi, to explore a section of the city and learn about the Pokemon they meet. Naturally, the kids are in for different but interesting experiences: Satoshi and Pikachu show their kids Pokemon-battling (getting involved in a Pokemon World Championship ranking match along the way), and Go goes on a Pokemon-catching spree with his duo. Trouble strikes when Rocket-Dan try to steal Pikachu, Rabbifuto and Wanpachi using a fake Lugia.
Title           = Hit Your Mark, Wave Guidance! Satoshi and the Mysterious Egg!
TranslitTitle   = Todoke-ha shirube! Satoshi to fushigina tamago! !
NativeTitle     = とどけ波導！サトシと不思議なタマゴ！！

ShortSummary    = As a change of pace, Satoshi and Go go out looking for Pokemon eggs, but encounter Hashiba, who challenges Satoshi to a Pokemon World Championship ranking match, but his Kentauros is defeated by Pikachu. While Pikachu is being treated at the Kuchiba City Pokemon Center, a Pokemon egg there from the Sinnoh Region that hasn't been willing to hatch yet reacts to Satoshi, and Joy-san entrusts the egg to him. That night at the Sakuragi Institute, the egg hatches to reveal a Riolu, who runs away and starts attacking wild Pokemon indiscriminately, including an Iwark that may be too strong for Riolu unless Satoshi and Pikachu can get there in time.
NativeTitle     = さよなら、ラビフット！

ShortSummary    = The rift between Rabbifuto and Go seems to be getting worse and worse. Now Satoshi and Go have gone to the Hoenn Region to investigate a mysterious phenomenon, and when Go tries to catch a Kemusso Rabbifuto refuses to obey him! Unless Go can figure out what's going on with Rabbifuto he may lose his partner forever.
Title           = A Massive Panic! Sakuragi Park!!
NativeTitle     = 大パニック！サクラギパーク！！

ShortSummary    = All the food in the Sakuragi Park has disappeared, and all the Pokemon there are starting to fight out of hunger. Satoshi and Go decide to stake out the park overnight  to catch the culprit.

ShortSummary    = Rocket-Dan receives orders from Sakaki to take a vacation, and this order apparently applies to all Rocket-Dan members, but while they're taking things easy Matori and her Elite Team swoop into the area and start snatching up Pokemon! Now Musashi, Kojiro, Nyarth and Sonans have to work with Satoshi and Go to stop Matori without either the two Trainers finding out who they are or violating their orders from Headquarters.
Title           = A Battle Festival Exploding With Life! VS Mega Lucario!!
TranslitTitle   = Inochi bakuhatsu batorufesu! VS megarukario! !
NativeTitle     = 命爆発バトルフェス！VSメガルカリオ！！
prev_season          = [[List of Pokémon the Series: Sun & Moon – Ultra Legends episodes

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: '''''Pocket Monsters''''' (ポケットモンスター) is the twenty-third season of the [[Pokémon (anime)
19th-century German pianist and composer: ''Pokémon'' animated series]] internationally. The series premiered on November 17, 2019 on [[TV Tokyo]] in Japan. The series premiered on April 8, 2020 on Seoul Broadcasting System and Tooniverse in South Korea. This season follows the adventures of [[Ash Ketchum]] (voiced in Japanese by [[Rika Matsumoto]] and in Korean by Lee Seon-Ho) and new protagonist, Go (voiced in Japanese by [[Daiki Yamashita]] and in Korean by Song Harim) as they travel across [[Pokémon universe#Regions
column3: all 8 regions]] of the ''[[Pokémon]]'' franchise, including the new Galar region from [[Pokémon Sword and Shield
column10: title=New 'Pokémon' Anime Trailer Confirms Upcoming Series to Include Ash, Pikachu and New Character

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The Japanese opening song is \"One, Two, Three\" (１・２・３ ワン・ツー・スリ, Wan, Tsū, Surī) by After the Rain's Soraru and Mafumafu and the Japanese ending songs are \"Pokémon Shiritori (Pikachu → Mew Ver.)\" (ポケモンしりとり ピカチュウ→ミュウver., Pokémon Shiritori Pikachū → Myū Ver.) for 18 episodes, and \"Pokemon Shiritori (Mew → Zamazenta Ver.)\" (ポケモンしりとり ミュウ→ザマゼンタver., Pokémon Shiritori Myū → Zamazenta Ver.) by the Pokémon Music Club's Pokémon Kids 2019 starting in episode 20. The Korean opening song is \"Start of a Journey\" (여행의 시작, Yeohaeng-ui Sijak) by Lee Il-song and the Korean ending song is \"Memorizing Pokémon Names\" (포켓몬 이름 외우기, Pokémon Ireum Oeugi) by Cha$e.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=After the Rain’s New Pokémon Anime Full OP Released on Mafumafu’s Channel
column5: access-date=2019-11-17}}</ref><ref>Pokémon Music Club's Pokémon Kids 2019's new Pokémon TV Size ED Released on Natalie Music's Website. Retrieved 2019-11-24</ref>

19th-century German pianist and composer: ShortSummary    = In this prequel episode, Pikachu's backstory as a Pichu, his being cared for by a Kangaskhan after falling off a cliff and the events leading to his evolution into a Pikachu are revealed.
Title           = Satoshi, Go, and Lugia Go!
TranslitTitle   = Satoshi to gō, rugia de gō!
NativeTitle     = サトシとゴウ、ルギアでゴー！

ShortSummary    = Satoshi, Hanako, Barri-chan and Professor Okido travel to Kuchiba City to attend the opening of Professor Sakuragi's new research lab. The sudden appearance of Lugia causes Satoshi to meet Go, a new Trainer with his own dream, and both of them to go on the ride of a lifetime to learn more about Lugia.
NativeTitle     = フシギソウってフシギだね？

ShortSummary    = A bunch of Fushigisou are causing chaos throughout Kuchiba City, and Professor Sakuragi sends Satoshi and Go to investigate. While learning the cause of the trouble, they not only learn more about each other but also clash with Rocket-Dan; however, the evil trio are now using Monster Balls supplied by Sakaki and delivered by a Pelipper that arrives whenever they call it. The Fushigisou use Solar Beam to defeat Rocket-Dan and evolve into Fushigibana.
Title           = Let's Go to the Galar Region! An Encounter with Hibanny!!
TranslitTitle   = Ikuze Gararu Chihō! Hibanī tono deai!!
NativeTitle     = 行くぜガラル地方！ヒバニーとの出会い！！

ShortSummary    = Satoshi and Go travel to the Galar Region to investigate reports that Pokemon are growing giant-sized, meeting up along the way with a mischievous Hibanny that seems to connect with Go.
Title           = Kabigon Became Gigantic!? The Mystery of Daimax!!
TranslitTitle   = Kabigon kyodai ka!? daimakkusu no nazo!!
NativeTitle     = カビゴン巨大化！？ダイマックスの謎！！

ShortSummary    = Satoshi and Go continue their investigation in Galar, encountering a Kabigon affected by the mysterious phenomenon, now called \"Daimax\". Meanwhile, the Hibanny from the previous episode has been following them.
Title           = Catch a Lot of Pokémon! The Path to Mew!!
TranslitTitle   = Pokemon tairyō getto daze! Myū e no michi!!
NativeTitle     = ポケモン大量ゲットだぜ！ミュウへの道！！
ShortSummary    = Go and Hibanny have become partners, but Go is still determined to catch Mew someday. However, he finds that catching certain Pokemon isn't as easy as he thinks.
Title           = The Hoenn Region, Site of Fierce Fights! The Battle Frontier Challenge!!
TranslitTitle   = Gekitō no Hōen chihō! Chōsen batoru furontia!!
NativeTitle     = 激闘のホウエン地方！挑戦バトルフロンティア！！

ShortSummary    = On hearing about the Hoenn Region's Battle Frontier Glass Flute Cup competition, Satoshi immediately signs both himself and Go up. Go's battling inexperience gets him knocked out in the first round, but Satoshi, Pikachu and Barrierd show him that battling can be fun.
Title           = Don't Lose, Pochama! The Sinnoh Drift Ice Race!!
TranslitTitle   = Makeruna Pochama! Shinō chihō ryū hyū shī su!!
NativeTitle     = 負けるなポッチャマ！シンオウ地方の流氷レース！！

ShortSummary    = Satoshi and Go meet a Pochama from the Sinnoh region that has run (actually swam) away from its owner Misaki. Traveling to Sinnoh to return it, they learn that Pochama ran away because of its jealousy toward Misaki's Gureggru, who is competing with Pochama for her attention. The two Pokemon decide to settle their quarrel by competing in the Pokémon Drift Ice Race, which Satoshi and Go decide to enter as well.
Title           = The Promise We Made That Day! The Houou Legend of Johto!!
TranslitTitle   = Ano hi no chikai! Jōto chihō no Hōō densetsu!!
NativeTitle     = あの日の誓い！ジョウト地方のホウオウ伝説！！

ShortSummary    = Reports of sightings of Houou, the Legendary Pokemon Satoshi and Pikachu saw long ago, in the Johto region sends Satoshi and Go to Johto in the hope of seeing it. At an ancient bell tower, they meet a boy who also wants to see Houou and his grandfather who has lost his belief in the Legendary Pokemon.
Title           = The Kairyu Paradise and the Hakuryu Trial!!
TranslitTitle   = Kairyū no rakuen, Hakuryū no shiren!
NativeTitle     = カイリューの楽園、ハクリューの試練！

ShortSummary    = Acting on reports about Kairyu, Satoshi and Go begin a search for a mysterious island that may be the Kairyu habitat. To get there, Go catches a Jugon to use as a Ride Pokemon, but its chasing a female Jugon it's fallen in love with sends them headlong into a storm; fortunately, they are rescued by Kairyu who bring them to their island. While learning about the Miniryu, Hakuryu and Kairyu that live there, Satoshi and Pikachu help a Hakuryu who's having trouble learning how to fly.
Title           = Koharu, Wanpachi and Sometimes Gangar Too
TranslitTitle   = Koharu to Wanpachi to, tokidoki, Gengā
NativeTitle     = コハルとワンパチと、時々、ゲンガー

ShortSummary    = A Gangar is revealed to be responsible for poltergeist activity at the Sakuragi Institute, and Satoshi and Go race to catch it. Meanwhile, Koharu isn't sure what her dream for the future is and whether or not she even likes Pokemon, but  returning to the lab she becomes caught up in the battle between Satoshi/Go and Gangar.
Title           = Daimax Battle! Dande, The Greatest of Them All!!
TranslitTitle   = Daimakkusu batoru! Saikyō ōja Dande!!
NativeTitle     = ダイマックスバトル！最強王者ダンデ！！

ShortSummary    = Professor Sakuragi give Satoshi and Go tickets to the World Champion League, which is being held in Galar's Shoot City. Satoshi and Go discover that Daimax can be controlled in the final battle between Wataru and Dande, a battle in which Dande's Lizardon defeats Wataru's Gyarados. Meanwhile, Rocket-Dan attempts to capture a Kajirigame by battling it with a Madatsubomi, but Kajirigame then goes into Daimax form and goes on a rampage.
Title           = Satoshi vs. Dande! The Road to the Strongest!!
TranslitTitle   = Satoshi tai dande! Saikyō e no michi! !
NativeTitle     = サトシ対ダンデ！最強への道！！

ShortSummary    = While the Daimax Kajirigame chases Rocket-Dan, Satoshi and Go lure it to them and battle with Pikachu and Hibanny. When a strike from the Daimax Kajirigame cracks open the ground and releases energy, Pikachu becomes a Daimax Pikachu without the use of a Daimax Band. With help from Dande, Satoshi and Pikachu defeat Kajirigame, with both Pokemon returning to normal after the battle. Satoshi asks to have a battle with Dande, who later sneaks up on Satoshi and Go while they're discussing the different levels of the World Tournament and agrees to battle Satoshi.
Title           = First Visit to the Unova Region! Raid Battle in the Ruins!!
TranslitTitle   = Hatsu isshu chihō! Iseki de reidobatoru! !
NativeTitle     = 初イッシュ地方！遺跡でレイドバトル！！

ShortSummary    = Satoshi and Go travel to the Unova Region to explore the Ruins of the Titan, which are located in the middle of the Desert Resort. Due to the hot sand making walking difficult, Pokemon Ranger Keira suggests that they use their Pokemon to sled across. Reaching the ruin, Satoshi, Go and Keira meet the Group Leader. They explore the ruins, but find the path to face the Ancient Titan, a giant Golugh, is set with deadly traps, leading up to a battle.
Title           = Snow Day, Where Is Karakara's Bone?
TranslitTitle   = Yuki no hi, Karakara no hone wa doko?
NativeTitle     = 雪の日、カラカラのホネはどこ？

ShortSummary    = With the systems down at the Sakuragi Institute due to a major snowfall, Go decides to go home to visit his family. While waiting for his parents to arrive, he and Hibanny spot a Karakara being bullied by a gang of Mankeys. When the Mankeys steal Karakara's bone, Go, Hibanny and some of his Pokemon decide to help Karakara get its precious bone back. Meanwhile, because Go had left behind his present to his parents, Satoshi and Pikachu come looking for Go, and after learning what happened volunteer to help.

ShortSummary    = The Gangar that \"haunted\" the Sakuragi lab is back, and it's as mischievous as ever! Satoshi and Go resume their race to catch it, but it gets away. Go starts insinuating that Gangar might be back to curse Satoshi, and all of a sudden weird accidents start happening to Satoshi. Later, he literally runs into a Trainer whom Gangar (who's been hiding in Satoshi's shadow) recognizes as its former Trainer who had abandoned it. Satoshi intervenes when the enraged Gangar attacks its former Trainer, and Rocket-Dan (who've been watching from the sidelines) decides that they want Gangar for themselves.
Title           = Hibanny, Use Your Flaming Kick! Face Tomorrow!!
TranslitTitle   = Hibanī, honō no kikku! Asunimukatte! !
NativeTitle     = ヒバニー、炎のキック！明日に向かって！！

ShortSummary    = While battle-practicing with Satoshi and Pikachu, Hibanny is teased by Go's Hihidaruma into using a Fire-type move, but things don't go well. Hibanny is frustrated, and when Go seems unsympathetic Hibanny runs away. It manages to learn Sparks, but Go is too interested in catching Pokemon to notice. Chasing after a Pelipper, Go and Hibanny run into Rocket-Dan, who attack them using a Nyorobon and a Kamukame. Hibanny is quickly defeated when its Sparks move fails again, and Satoshi and Pikachu have to jump in, with Pikachu \"blasting off\" Rocket-Dan. When Go again seems unsympathetic, Hibanny runs away again and again runs into Rocket-Dan, who battle it again. This time, Go and Hibanny work as a team, causing Hibanny to evolve into Rabbifuto, whose new Sparks Kick move defeats Rocket-Dan. However, in the battle's aftermath, the relationship between Go and the former Hibanny may never be the same again.
Title           = Satoshi Takes Part! The Pokémon World Championships!!
TranslitTitle   = Satoshi sansen! Pokémon wārudo chanpionshippusu! !
NativeTitle     = サトシ参戦！ポケモンワールドチャンピオンシップス！！

ShortSummary    = In order to boost his ranking in the Pokémon World Championship, Satoshi and Pikachu, with Go and Rabbifuto, head out to the Kuchiba Gym to face their old opponent Matis. However, with Matis away, the gym is now being run by Visquez. Their battle is a two-on-two match officiated by a Rotom Drone, with Pikachu staring out for Satoshi and Raichu starting out for Visquez. During the battle, Satoshi recalls Pikachu and sends out Gangar, who defeats Raichu. Visquez sends out Marumine, who defeats Gangar, so it's all up to Pikachu ... and Rabbifuto is watching closely!
NativeTitle     = ワタシはメタモン！

ShortSummary    = Musashi still has dreams of being an actress, so she and Rocket-Dan try to sneak into a studio shooting a film in which one of the actors is a Metamon that can't transform properly. Terrified by the film's dictatorial director, Metamon runs away by secretly hiding in Musashi's bag, and when Rocket-Dan finds it after returning to their hideout, Musashi decides she's going to train it to transform properly. Meanwhile, Satoshi and Go are searching for the missing Metamon.
Title           = Go Towards Your Dream! Satoshi and Go!!
TranslitTitle   = Yume e mukatte gō! Satoshi to Gō!!
NativeTitle     = 夢へ向かってゴー！サトシとゴウ！！

ShortSummary    = Today is Pokemon Orientation Day at the Sakuragi Institute! The six visiting children are split into three teams: Team Blue escorted by Satoshi and Pikachu; Team Red by Go, Rabbifuto and Koharu; and Team Yellow by Professor Sakuragi and Koharu's Wanpachi, to explore a section of the city and learn about the Pokemon they meet. Naturally, the kids are in for different but interesting experiences: Satoshi and Pikachu show their kids Pokemon-battling (getting involved in a Pokemon World Championship ranking match along the way), and Go goes on a Pokemon-catching spree with his duo. Trouble strikes when Rocket-Dan try to steal Pikachu, Rabbifuto and Wanpachi using a fake Lugia.
Title           = Hit Your Mark, Wave Guidance! Satoshi and the Mysterious Egg!
TranslitTitle   = Todoke-ha shirube! Satoshi to fushigina tamago! !
NativeTitle     = とどけ波導！サトシと不思議なタマゴ！！

ShortSummary    = As a change of pace, Satoshi and Go go out looking for Pokemon eggs, but encounter Hashiba, who's also Pokemon egg-hunting. Hashiba challenges Satoshi to a Pokemon World Championship ranking match, but his Kentauros is defeated by Pikachu. While Pikachu is being treated at the Kuchiba City Pokemon Center, a Pokemon egg there from the Sinnoh Region that hasn't been willing to hatch yet reacts to Satoshi, and Joy-san entrusts the egg to him. That night at the Sakuragi Institute, the egg hatches to reveal a Riolu, who runs away and starts attacking wild Pokemon indiscriminately, including an Iwark that may be too strong for Riolu unless Satoshi and Pikachu can get there in time.
NativeTitle     = さよなら、ラビフット！

ShortSummary    = The rift between Rabbifuto and Go seems to be getting worse and worse. Now Satoshi and Go have gone to the Hoenn Region to investigate a mysterious phenomenon, and when Go tries to catch a Kemusso Rabbifuto refuses to obey him! Unless Go can figure out what's going on with Rabbifuto he may lose his partner forever.
Title           = A Massive Panic! Sakuragi Park!!
NativeTitle     = 大パニック！サクラギパーク！！

ShortSummary    = All the food in the Sakuragi Park has disappeared, and all the Pokemon there are starting to fight out of hunger. Satoshi and Go decide to stake out the park overnight  to catch the culprit.

ShortSummary    = Rocket-Dan receives orders from Sakaki to take a vacation, and this order apparently applies to all Rocket-Dan members, but while they're taking things easy Matori and her Elite Team swoop into the area and start snatching up Pokemon! Now Musashi, Kojiro, Nyarth and Sonans have to work with Satoshi and Go to stop Matori without either the two Trainers finding out who they are or violating their orders from Headquarters.
Title           = A Battle Festival Exploding With Life! VS Mega Lucario!!
TranslitTitle   = Inochi bakuhatsu batorufesu! VS megarukario! !
NativeTitle     = 命爆発バトルフェス！VSメガルカリオ！！

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: This article is about the '''Rolling stock of the Epping Ongar Railway'''.

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''Large Prairie 4141''' is a [[GWR 5101 Class]] locomotive. Built in 1946 it is a medium-sized tank engine with a [[2-6-2]]T wheel arrangement and was designed for suburban and local passenger trains, often seen with GWR and BR suburban coaches. At time of purchase it had recently received a boiler certificate which would see it run for up to ten years, securing the position of steam when the two other residents' boiler tickets had expired.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Two Arrivals Destined to Steam onto EOR - Epping Ongar Railway - News
column10: url-status=dead}}</ref> Arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2012, just in time for the \"Santa Specials\" in December 2012. It is out of service awaiting boiler repairs.

column3: 4900 Class ''Hall'']] locomotive, designed by [[Charles Collett]]. Built at [[Swindon Works]] in August 1929 at a cost of £4,375, it was allocated to Bristol, Bath Road shed. It carries GWR ‘Transitional’ (1945–48) livery, and is more than capable of handling the gradients of the line.<ref name=\"eorailway.co.uk\">{{cite web
column10: df=dmy-all }}</ref> It arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2012, Its boiler ticket expired in 2013 and underwent an overhaul including extensive boiler repair.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: url-status=dead }}</ref> The locomotive returned to service wearing British Railways lined black livery. When she returned to service the engine was facing east but when came back to the railway after attending the winter gala at its former home [[Great Central Railway (preserved)
column17: Great Central Railway]] The engine now faces west.

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''''Isabel''''' is a [[0-6-0]]ST by [[Hawthorn Leslie]] (works number 3437/1919) These locomotives were mostly used for industrial purposes, and Isabel is an extremely powerful engine, entirely suitable for the steep gradients on the EOR and quite capable of hauling 2-3 coach trains on low-season days{{citation needed
column3: date=February 2016}}. It has an enlarged cab, and so is ideal for training crews and for undertaking \"driver experience\" courses.Arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2010, Isabel returned to steam on the EOR's Autumn steam gala 2017. Boiler ticket expires 2027.<ref>{{cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''47635''' was built in 1964 and entered traffic in the same year. Numbered originally D1606, it was renumbered to 47029 in 1974 and 47635 in 1986. It was Named \"Jimmy Milne\" in 1987. It was renamed \"The Lass O'Ballochmyle\" in 2003. It went back to \"Jimmy Milne\" in preservation at the [[Swanage Railway]] in 2008. It is currently in BR Blue with yellow ends.<ref>{{Cite web

'''D6729''' was built in 1961 and is resident on Epping Ongar. Following its withdrawal from main-line freight workings, it was restored and repainted to its original colours. It is currently in BR Green and is Operational.<ref>{{Cite web

'''31438''' was built in 1959. Arrived on the [[Mid-Norfolk Railway]] on 24 November 2001, being delivered by road from Carlisle.  On arrival at Dereham the original fault book from 31235 was found inside it, both locomotives having been stored at Upperby shed.  The locomotive is one of a number fitted with electric train heating.  It was delivered new to Ipswich shed as D5557, being transferred to Norwich between 1961 and 1965.  It used to carry a unique livery of Brunswick Green with BR arrow symbols.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: format=}}</ref>  It was listed for sale in late August 2011,<ref>{{cite web
column21: df=dmy-all}}</ref> was sold to the Epping Ongar Railway by September, and left the MNR after their Autumn Gala.<ref>{{cite web
column27: work=wnxx.com}}</ref> It is currently in BR Blue and is Operational.<ref>{{Cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''45132''' was built as D22 in 1961 by BR Derby works. It was converted to electric in the 1970s and renumbered 45132. It was withdrawn in 1987, and stored at March in Cambridgeshire. It is currently in BR Blue, Undergoing heavy overhaul.<ref>http://www.eorailway.co.uk/enthusiasts/rolling-stock/diesel-locomotives/#45132</ref>
'''D7523''' was built by British Railways at Derby in 1965 and started its career at [[Toton TMD]] before moving around various [[London Midland Region of British Railways
column3: London Midland Region]] sheds such as [[Willesden TMD
column6: Crewe]]. It was renumbered 25173 in 1974.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title= The Allocation History of BR Diesels and Electrics
column14: location= Bromsgrove }}</ref> It had been based at the [[Crewe Heritage Centre]] and on the [[West Somerset Railway]].<ref>{{cite book
column21: location= Taunton}}</ref> It arrived at the railway on 7 September 2011 and will be used for engineering and ballast trains and for maintenance and testing of vacuum-braked coaches.<ref>{{cite web
column25: work=Epping Ongar Railway - News}}</ref> It is currently in BR Green, Undergoing heavy overhaul.<ref>{{Cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''03170''' was delivered to British Railways as D2170 in 1960. It is currently in BR Blue, Operational but restricted to yard use.<ref>{{Cite web

'''03119''' was built in 1959, it is an unusual locomotive as it was modified with a \"cut down\" cab. It now resides on the EOR as one of the shunting locomotives. It is currently in BR Blue, it is stored out of traffic.<ref>{{Cite web
'''RH 398616''' of 1956 is out of service. All salvageable parts have been removed and the unit is on static display on a plinth by the main road at Ongar.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Up, Up and Away! - Epping Ongar Railway - News

19th-century German pianist and composer: Unit DMBS 51342 and DMS 51384 Set No -
The railway has the two driving cars from what was a three-car [[British Rail Class 117
column3: Class 117 DMU]]. There were 127 of this type of vehicle and they were delivered new in 1959 to Southall depot working services between Paddington and the suburbs. They continued to be based in the London area until withdrawal in the 1990s, they arrived at the Railway in 2004. Each coach has two [[Leyland Motors
column4: Leyland]] [[diesel engine]]s underneath, which drive the wheels mechanically through a [[fluid flywheel]]. The driver's cab at each end of the unit means it can be driven from either end, making it ideal when running to [[Coopersale]], and speeding up turn-around times. The windows in the ends mean passengers in either coach get an excellent view of the line ahead or behind and also get to watch the driver in action. The unit ran in an unusual dark blue and white 'EOR' livery until 2007, when it was taken out of service by the new owner when services were suspended. The interior has been refurbished, the unit is receiving attention to the exterior bodywork. DMBS is being restored; DMS is in service twinned with a Class 121 unpowered driving trailer.<ref>http://eorailway.co.uk/departments/rolling-stock/mus/{{Dead link

19th-century German pianist and composer: DMBS is being restored; DMS operational.
The railway has a 2-car 1957 \"Hampshire\" [[British Rail Class 205
column3: Class 205 DEMU]] 205205. It has been brought back to the South East from the [[North Yorkshire Moors Railway]], and has been restored and again carries passengers. It is the usual motive power for the trains towards Epping. 205205 is the only unit with a corridor connection as it was experimentally converted and modernised by British Rail. The volunteer team at EOR has restored the unit, complete with its commuter-style interior and is now painted in former \"Network SouthEast\" livery. This ensures the preservation of this period of transport history and is attractive to film and TV companies who require a train of that era. It arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2009. It is Out of Traffic - available as coaching stock.<ref>http://eorailway.co.uk/departments/rolling-stock/mus/{{Dead link

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Epping Ongar Railway has an affinity with [[electric multiple unit]] (EMU) preservation, as the branch used [[London Underground rolling stock
19th-century German pianist and composer: LT's electric stock]] from 1957 until 1994. There was talk of the line being electrified by the [[London and North Eastern Railway
column3: LNER]] with overhead electrification before the [[Second World War]] intervened. Some local lines were electrified quite early on, for example to Shenfield and Southend, and the next generations of EMUs continue to work services on those lines into Liverpool Street.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: While the 3rd & 4th conductor rails were removed by the new owners, the line still hosts electric style units, though without the electrification they are hauled by a [[diesel locomotive]]. Due to cost, safety issues and legislation it is not possible to re-electrify the branch.

19th-century German pianist and composer: Built in 1956, arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2016. This unit contains the only surviving Bep buffet car, the unit is running in the refurbished condition.  The 2 motor coaches are currently at Eastleigh works for the rebuilding of the brake (guards) compartment in the original position. The trailer coaches are at the Epping Ongar Railway. The trailers are stored under restoration.<ref>http://www.cep7105.co.uk/</ref>

Built in 1959, withdrawn in 2000 and stored at Morden Depot. Donated in 2018 to the Epping Ongar due to being in the way of construction works. Currently used as a museum of the history of the railway.<ref>http://www.eorailway.co.uk/enthusiasts/rolling-stock/multiple-units/#1959stock/</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The most iconic carriage design of the LNER, these lasted well into BR ownership. Finalised in 1923, the design utilised a 60 ft underframe, with more traditional squared moulding and windows and wooden teak-panelled bodies. There are two examples on the EOR a Buffet car and Brake Tourist Open (BTO) examples..

19th-century German pianist and composer: The BTO, a six-bay open saloon, has seating for up to 48 passengers, and was built in 1938, it is believed to be the last surviving 6-bay Gresley coach built to diagram D196. Arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2014. Stored awaiting Restoration.<ref>{{Cite web

The buffet was built in 1936. After a short stay a Quainton Road, where it was used to serve refreshments, the carriage was then moved to Chappel and Wakes Colne in 1972. Restoration had, by this stage, been commenced, but was stalled as priority was given to a BTO (which later moved to the North Yorkshire Moors Railway.) The Buffet was moved again in 2001 to the workshops at Ovington and where the coach finally received covered accommodation. The owner decided in 2010, that carriage would fit in well here, and after needing to vacate the site at Ovington, the ownership of carriage was transferred to Epping Ongar Railway Holdings Limited, on the understanding that, in due course, it would be restored to its former glory. The carriage arrived at North Weald in 2010. Stored awaitng Restoration.<ref>{{Cite web

Out of Service, painted in Blue and Grey.<ref>http://www.cs.vintagecarriagestrust.org/se/CarriageInfo.asp?Ref=2919</ref>

Operational,Used to spread track ballast after it has been laid, as well as a guards brake van on engineers trains. It has recently undergone a full restoration, being outshopped in BR Engineer's Black.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=8891</ref>

Undergoing Restoration. Once restored this vehicle will also be used for engineering and demonstration freight trains, as well as infrequent brake van rides.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=9710</ref>

Awaiting restoration, Once a common sight at the end of every goods train, this van ended its life being used by London Transport when transferring its Heritage fleet around the Underground network. It is on loan from the London Transport Museum, and has been restored into its original BR (unfitted) light grey livery, complete with many original fittings.<ref>{{Cite web

Operational, These wagons were designed for the freight to and from the continent as BR updated its rolling stock. The design was introduced in 1975 and they had a number of uses and liveries, being very useful with both sliding and opening doors, enabling direct access to all parts of the vehicle. This van was used by the army, and still carries the identity \"WGB 4311\".<ref>{{Cite web

Operational, The Fruit 'D' vans were the last type of 'Fruit' vehicle built by the Great Western to aid some of their traffic of garden produce. The vans had additional ventilation slats in the sides to allow cool air to circulate, as well as three sets of double doors on each side and internal gas lighting, on an 18 ft wheelbase. As well as the carriage of fruit, they were also found being used for express parcels traffic.<ref>{{Cite web

Operational, Once numerous and used for the transportation of all kinds of parcels and merchandise. Since arriving at the railway in army livery (carrying the number WGB 4182 as pictured left), it has been restored into original BR Bauxite livery, complete with sign-written numbers.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=8893</ref>
Used as stores, grounded body at North Weald station.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=14377</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: === Flat wagons, bolster wagons and Rail and Sleeper wagons ===

19th-century German pianist and composer: Stored, Built for the Great Western Railway and designed to carry rails for the track engineers, a purpose for which it is still very useful.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=7672</ref>

Operational, Built for carrying Army tanks (hence the telegraphic name) and latterly used by the engineers' departments for carrying heavy plant and equipment. This vehicle is very useful with its 38.5t capacity, and a team has completely restored it, repainting the frames and replacing all the wooden decking, finishing off with its lettering.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=8895</ref>

Operational,With doors able to spread ballast to all parts of the track (either side and down the middle), this is a useful ballast-carrying vehicle.<ref>http://www.ws.rhrp.org.uk/ws/WagonInfo.asp?Ref=9709</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: === Cranes and other special use wagons ===

19th-century German pianist and composer: Stored but Movable; crane mechanism non-operational, Once used for light engineering works and in BR yellow livery, it has its runner and match trucks. The vehicle can be moved, but the crane is no longer operational.<ref>{{Cite web

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: [[Category:Lists of locomotives and rolling stock preserved on heritage railways in England
This article is about the '''Rolling stock of the Epping Ongar Railway'''.

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''Large Prairie 4141''' is a [[GWR 5101 Class]] locomotive. Built in 1946 it is a medium-sized tank engine with a [[2-6-2]]T wheel arrangement and was designed for suburban and local passenger trains, often seen with GWR and BR suburban coaches. At time of purchase it had recently received a boiler certificate which would see it run for up to ten years, securing the position of steam when the two other residents' boiler tickets had expired.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Two Arrivals Destined to Steam onto EOR - Epping Ongar Railway - News
column10: url-status=dead}}</ref> Arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2012, just in time for the \"Santa Specials\" in December 2012. It is out of service awaiting boiler repairs.

column3: 4900 Class ''Hall'']] locomotive, designed by [[Charles Collett]]. Built at [[Swindon Works]] in August 1929 at a cost of £4,375, it was allocated to Bristol, Bath Road shed. It carries GWR ‘Transitional’ (1945–48) livery, and is more than capable of handling the gradients of the line.<ref name=\"eorailway.co.uk\">{{cite web
column10: df=dmy-all }}</ref> It arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2012, Its boiler ticket expired in 2013 and underwent an overhaul including extensive boiler repair.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: url-status=dead }}</ref> The locomotive returned to service wearing British Railways lined black livery. When she returned to service the engine was facing east but when came back to the railway after attending the winter gala at it's former home [[Great Central Railway (preserved)
column17: Great Central Railway]] The engine now faces west.

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''''Isabel''''' is a [[0-6-0]]ST by [[Hawthorn Leslie]] (works number 3437/1919) These locomotives were mostly used for industrial purposes, and Isabel is an extremely powerful engine, entirely suitable for the steep gradients on the EOR and quite capable of hauling 2-3 coach trains on low-season days{{citation needed
column3: date=February 2016}}. It has an enlarged cab, and so is ideal for training crews and for undertaking \"driver experience\" courses.Arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2010, Isabel returned to steam on the EOR's Autumn steam gala 2017. Boiler ticket expires 2027.<ref>{{cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''47635''' was built in 1964 and entered traffic in the same year. Numbered originally D1606, it was renumbered to 47029 in 1974 and 47635 in 1986. It was Named \"Jimmy Milne\" in 1987. It was renamed \"The Lass O'Ballochmyle\" in 2003. It went back to \"Jimmy Milne\" in preservation at the [[Swanage Railway]] in 2008. It is currently in BR Blue with yellow ends.<ref>{{Cite web

'''D6729''' was built in 1961 and is resident on Epping Ongar. Following its withdrawal from main-line freight workings, it was restored and repainted to its original colours. It is currently in BR Green and is Operational.<ref>{{Cite web

'''31438''' was built in 1959. Arrived on the [[Mid-Norfolk Railway]] on 24 November 2001, being delivered by road from Carlisle.  On arrival at Dereham the original fault book from 31235 was found inside it, both locomotives having been stored at Upperby shed.  The locomotive is one of a number fitted with electric train heating.  It was delivered new to Ipswich shed as D5557, being transferred to Norwich between 1961 and 1965.  It used to carry a unique livery of Brunswick Green with BR arrow symbols.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: format=}}</ref>  It was listed for sale in late August 2011,<ref>{{cite web
column21: df=dmy-all}}</ref> was sold to the Epping Ongar Railway by September, and left the MNR after their Autumn Gala.<ref>{{cite web
column27: work=wnxx.com}}</ref> It is currently in BR Blue and is Operational.<ref>{{Cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''45132''' was built as D22 in 1961 by BR Derby works. It was converted to electric in the 1970s and renumbered 45132. It was withdrawn in 1987, and stored at March in Cambridgeshire. It is currently in BR Blue, Undergoing heavy overhaul.<ref>http://www.eorailway.co.uk/enthusiasts/rolling-stock/diesel-locomotives/#45132</ref>
'''D7523''' was built by British Railways at Derby in 1965 and started its career at [[Toton TMD]] before moving around various [[London Midland Region of British Railways
column3: London Midland Region]] sheds such as [[Willesden TMD
column6: Crewe]]. It was renumbered 25173 in 1974.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title= The Allocation History of BR Diesels and Electrics
column14: location= Bromsgrove }}</ref> It had been based at the [[Crewe Heritage Centre]] and on the [[West Somerset Railway]].<ref>{{cite book
column21: location= Taunton}}</ref> It arrived at the railway on 7 September 2011 and will be used for engineering and ballast trains and for maintenance and testing of vacuum-braked coaches.<ref>{{cite web
column25: work=Epping Ongar Railway - News}}</ref> It is currently in BR Green, Undergoing heavy overhaul.<ref>{{Cite web

19th-century German pianist and composer: '''03170''' was delivered to British Railways as D2170 in 1960. It is currently in BR Blue, Operational but restricted to yard use.<ref>{{Cite web

'''03119''' was built in 1959, it is an unusual locomotive as it was modified with a \"cut down\" cab. It now resides on the EOR as one of the shunting locomotives. It is currently in BR Blue, it is stored out of traffic.<ref>{{Cite web
'''RH 398616''' of 1956 is out of service. All salvageable parts have been removed and the unit is on static display on a plinth by the main road at Ongar.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Up, Up and Away! - Epping Ongar Railway - News

19th-century German pianist and composer: Unit DMBS 51342 and DMS 51384 Set No -
The railway has the two driving cars from what was a three-car [[British Rail Class 117
column3: Class 117 DMU]]. There were 127 of this type of vehicle and they were delivered new in 1959 to Southall depot working services between Paddington and the suburbs. They continued to be based in the London area until withdrawal in the 1990s, they arrived at the Railway in 2004. Each coach has two [[Leyland Motors
column4: Leyland]] [[diesel engine]]s underneath, which drive the wheels mechanically through a [[fluid flywheel]]. The driver's cab at each end of the unit means it can be driven from either end, making it ideal when running to [[Coopersale]], and speeding up turn-around times. The windows in the ends mean passengers in either coach get an excellent view of the line ahead or behind and also get to watch the driver in action. The unit ran in an unusual dark blue and white 'EOR' livery until 2007, when it was taken out of service by the new owner when services were suspended. The interior has been refurbished, the unit is receiving attention to the exterior bodywork. DMBS is being restored; DMS is in service twinned with a Class 121 unpowered driving trailer.<ref>http://eorailway.co.uk/departments/rolling-stock/mus/{{Dead link

19th-century German pianist and composer: DMBS is being restored; DMS operational.
The railway has a 2-car 1957 \"Hampshire\" [[British Rail Class 205
column3: Class 205 DEMU]] 205205. It has been brought back to the South East from the [[North Yorkshire Moors Railway]], and has been restored and again carries passengers. It is the usual motive power for the trains towards Epping. 205205 is the only unit with a corridor connection as it was experimentally converted and modernised by British Rail. The volunteer team at EOR has restored the unit, complete with its commuter-style interior and is now painted in former \"Network SouthEast\" livery. This ensures the preservation of this period of transport history and is attractive to film and TV companies who require a train of that era. It arrived at the Epping Ongar Railway in 2009. It is Out of Traffic - available as coaching stock.<ref>http://eorailway.co.uk/departments/rolling-stock/mus/{{Dead link

county]] located in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Indiana]].  As of the 2010 census, the population was 20,952.<ref name=\"census-quickfacts\">{{cite web
publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]}}</ref>  The [[county seat]] is [[Rockport, Indiana

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Spencer County was formed in 1818 from parts of [[Warrick County, Indiana
column3: Perry County]]. It was named for Captain [[Spier Spencer]], killed at the [[Battle of Tippecanoe]] in 1811. He was also the namesake for [[Spencer, Indiana]], the county seat of [[Owen County, Indiana
column5: author=De Witt Clinton Goodrich & Charles Richard Tuttle
column9: title=An Illustrated History of the State of Indiana

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: [[Abraham Lincoln]] lived in Spencer County from 1816 to 1830, between the ages of seven and twenty-one. Originally, the area his family settled in was in Perry County. His family moved to Illinois in 1830.  The [[Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial]] is located at the site of the Lincoln family farm.  In addition, the graves of his mother [[Nancy Lincoln]] and sister [[Sarah Lincoln Grigsby]] are located in Spencer County.
On December 16, 1900, two African-American men, Bud Rowlands and Jim Henderson, were [[Lynching in the United States
19th-century German pianist and composer: lynched]] by the county courthouse in Rockport after being arrested as suspects in the brutal robbery and killing of a white barber at 2 am the night before. A mob estimated at 1,500 broke open the jail and took them out, hanging them from a tree by the courthouse, and shooting their bodies numerous times.<ref name=\"lynch1900\">[http://genealogytrails.com/ind/spencer/news.html ''Butte Weekly Miner'', 20 December 1900; accessed 31 May 2018]</ref> John Rolla was accused by Rowlands as a suspect and also lynched.<ref name=\"marion\">[https://www.indystar.com/story/news/history/retroindy/2018/04/26/last-known-lynching-indiana-included-national-memorial-peace-and-justice/553199002/ Dawn Mitchell and Maureen C. Gilmer, \"Last-known lynching in Indiana included in National Memorial for Peace and Justice\"], ''Indy Star'', 30 April 2018; accessed 31 May 2018</ref> This was the second-highest number of lynchings in the state, though it pales in comparison to lynchings in Southern states.<ref name=\"lynching\">{{Cite web
column4: title=''Lynching in America''; Supplement: Lynching by County, 3rd edition, 2017, Montgomery, Alabama: Equal Justice Initiative, p. 5

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The current Spencer County courthouse was built in 1921. It is the fifth courthouse to serve the county.<ref>{{cite book
County attractions include the town of [[Santa Claus, Indiana
19th-century German pianist and composer: Santa Claus]], [[Holiday World & Splashin' Safari]], and [[Santa's Candy Castle]].

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: [[Saint Meinrad Archabbey]] is located at the northeastern corner of Spencer County.
According to the 2010 census, the county has a total area of {{convert

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[Recorder of deeds
column3: surveyor]], and circuit [[court clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column4: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Spencer County is part of [[Indiana's 8th congressional district]] and is represented in [[United States Congress

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Spencer County was formed in 1818 from parts of [[Warrick County, Indiana
column3: Perry County]]. It was named for Captain [[Spier Spencer]], killed at the [[Battle of Tippecanoe]] in 1811. He was also the namesake for [[Spencer, Indiana]], the county seat of [[Owen County, Indiana
column5: author=De Witt Clinton Goodrich & Charles Richard Tuttle
column9: title=An Illustrated History of the State of Indiana

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: [[Abraham Lincoln]] lived in Spencer County from 1816 to 1830, between the ages of seven and twenty-one. Originally, the area his family settled in was in Perry County. His family moved to Illinois in 1830.  The [[Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial]] is located at the site of the Lincoln family farm.  In addition, the graves of his mother [[Nancy Lincoln]] and sister [[Sarah Lincoln Grigsby]] are located in Spencer County.
On December 16, 1900, two African-American men, Bud Rowlands and Jim Henderson, were [[Lynching in the United States
19th-century German pianist and composer: lynched]] by the county courthouse in Rockport after being arrested as suspects in the brutal robbery and killing of a white barber at 2 am the night before. A mob estimated at 1,500 broke open the jail and took them out, hanging them from a tree by the courthouse, and shooting their bodies numerous times.<ref name=\"lynch1900\">[http://genealogytrails.com/ind/spencer/news.html ''Butte Weekly Miner'', 20 December 1900; accessed 31 May 2018]</ref> John Rolla was accused by Rowlands as a suspect and also lynched.<ref name=\"marion\">[https://www.indystar.com/story/news/history/retroindy/2018/04/26/last-known-lynching-indiana-included-national-memorial-peace-and-justice/553199002/ Dawn Mitchell and Maureen C. Gilmer, \"Last-known lynching in Indiana included in National Memorial for Peace and Justice\"], ''Indy Star'', 30 April 2018; accessed 31 May 2018</ref> This was the second-highest number of lynchings in the state, though it pales in comparison to lynchings in Southern states.<ref name=\"lynching\">{{Cite web
column4: title=''Lynching in America''; Supplement: Lynching by County, 3rd edition, 2017, Montgomery, Alabama: Equal Justice Initiative, p. 5

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[Recorder of deeds
column3: surveyor]], and circuit [[court clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column4: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: \"'''I Love Me'''\" is a song by American singer [[Demi Lovato]]. It was released on March 6, 2020 as the lead single from her seventh upcoming studio album. The track was written by Lovato alongside [[Anne-Marie (singer)
column3: Sean Douglas]], Alex Niceforo, Keith Sorrells and [[Oak Felder
column4: Warren \"Oak\" Felder]] and produced by the latter three. It is an upbeat [[pop music
column6: R&B]] song whose lyrics mainly talk about struggles with self-image.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A music video for \"I Love Me\" was directed by [[Hannah Lux Davis]] and filmed in [[New York City]]. It was released on March 6, 2020, and depicts Lovato walking across a street with several references to moments in her career and personal life. It has charted within the top 20 in Hungary, Scotland, and the United States as well as the top 30 in Canada and Ireland.
\"I Love Me\" was written by [[Demi Lovato]] alongside [[Anne-Marie (singer)
column3: Sean Douglas]], Alex Niceforo, Keith Sorrells and [[Oak Felder
column4: Warren \"Oak\" Felder]] and produced by the latter three.<ref name=\"Tidal\">{{cite web
column6: title=I Love Me / Demi Lovato – Credits
column9: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> According to Anne-Marie, she co-wrote the song with other songwriters in 2019 before Lovato heard it and recorded it.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Anne-Marie Praises Demi Lovato For New Song 'I Love Me' – Which She Helped Write
column15: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> During an interview with [[Ellen DeGeneres]], Lovato described the track as \"fun and lighthearted\" that had a \"positive, upbeat message\".<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Did Demi Lovato Call Out Wilmer Valderrama In New Music Video?

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: On March 2, 2020, she announced through her [[Instagram]] that her upcoming new single \"I Love Me\" would be released four days later, attaching the cover art to the post.<ref name=\"Teen Vogue\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato Announces New Song \"I Love Me\"
column8: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> The artwork is a blurry picture of Lovato wearing a red jacket on a city street with the title of the single in the left upper corner.<ref name=\"Teen Vogue\"/> Lovato had previously used the title of the single as a hashtag for another Instagram picture on February 24.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Demi Lovato to release new song 'I Love Me' on Friday
column17: title=Demi Lovato Looks Fresh & Healthy in Stunning #NoMakeupMonday Selfie
column23: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> \"I Love Me\" was released on March 6, 2020, on both [[Music download
column25: streaming]] platforms,<ref name=\"BBrel\"/> as the [[lead single]] from her upcoming seventh studio album.<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Demi Lovato Says Her Self-Care Routine Involves a Lot of 'Aromatherapy, Listening to Music and Crying'
column33: limited edition]] alternative cover signed CD singles of the song were made available for purchase for twenty-four hours via Lovato's official online store,<ref>{{Cite tweet
column35: title=Signed #ILoveMe CDs Available for 24 hours only https://DemiLovato.lnk.to/Shop pic.twitter.com/OMpITk1t5J
column38: accessdate=March 13, 2020}}</ref> On March 12, vinyls with a different alternative cover were released for approximately four hours.<ref>{{Cite tweet
column40: title=Signed #ILoveMe vinyl Available until 9pm PT / 12am ET http://DemiLovato.lnk.to/Shop pic.twitter.com/tL7kUkIQSo

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: \"I Love Me\" is an upbeat [[pop music
column5: title=Demi Lovato Confronts Her Past And Kicks Some Ass In 'I Love Me' Video
column12: title=Demi Lovato's Brutally Honest, Ass-Kicking Music Video for 'I Love Me' Is Here
column18: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> with a length of three minutes and twenty-three seconds.<ref name=\"Apple Music\"/> The chorus features drum instrumentation that stops while Lovato sings the line \"I wonder when 'I love me' is enough\".<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=First Stream: New Music From Megan Thee Stallion, Lil Uzi Vert, Demi Lovato & More

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In an interview with [[Apple Music]]'s Hanuman Welch, Lovato said \"I Love Me\" talked about \"loving yourself\", adding, \"It's an anthem, and it talks about how hard we are on ourselves and this, the negative self-talk. You know, how easily we can listen to that. But when is loving yourself gonna be enough?\".<ref name=\"ETO\"/> During ''[[the Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' she explained the title of the song, saying, \"We are good by ourselves. We don't need a partner, we don't need, like, substance. We're good.\"<ref name=\"ETO\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato \"Taking a Little Bit More Time\" Working on Her New Album Amid Comeback
column8: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> During the first verse, Lovato sings about her past problems with eating disorders and body image, \"Can't see what I am, I just see what I'm not / I'm guilty 'bout everything that I eat (every single day)\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Demi Lovato's New Single \"I Love Me\" Is the Self-Love Anthem We Need but Don't Deserve
column18: title=Demi Lovato Gets Extremely Personal About Her Past Struggles in the Lyrics to Her New Song 'I Love Me'

19th-century German pianist and composer: Billboard]]'' said the song was about Lovato's \"battle with her mental health\", as exemplified in the chorus, \"Oh, why do I compare myself to everyone?/ And I always got my finger on the self-destruct/ I wonder when I love me is enough\".<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The 13 Best Things That Happened in Music This Week (March 6)
column9: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Rania Aniftos of the same magazine described \"I Love Me\" as a \"self-love\" and \"empowering\" song.<ref name=\"BBrel\">{{cite web
column11: title=Demi Lovato Drops Self-Love Single 'I Love Me' & Video: Watch
column16: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Marcus Jones of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' said the track focused on \"self-love\" and noted it was more upbeat than Lovato's previous single, \"Anyone\".<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Demi Lovato declares 'I Love Me' in empowering new anthem: Watch the video
column23: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Kelly Wynne of ''[[Newsweek]]'' also deemed it as a \"ode to self and the powers each person holds as an individual.\"<ref name=\"Newsweek\"/>

19th-century German pianist and composer: Vulture]]'' deemed \"I Love Me\" as a \"rousing, introspective pop song about self-love and self-doubt\".<ref name=\"Vulture\"/> Mike Nied of ''[[Idolator (website)
column3: Idolator]]'' called the song a \"bop with a very important message\", adding it \"packs just as much personality as '[[Sorry Not Sorry (Demi Lovato song)
column4: Sorry Not Sorry]]' but feels more elevated\".<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Is An Essential Self-Empowerment Anthem
column12: accessdate=March 8, 2020}}</ref> Claire Shaffer and Althea Legaspi of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' praised the music video in an article entitled \"Demi Lovato Confidently Showcases 'I Love Me' is Enough in New Music Video\", saying \"Her confident stride and dancing showcases the resilience that's found in learning to love one's self.\"<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Demi Lovato Confidently Showcases 'I Love Me' is Enough in New Video
column22: Billboard]]'', referring to the lyric video that depicts vintage New York City, said that \"The way Lovato picks herself up in the song and transmits that uplifting message to her fans is seen in the low-angle skyscraper shots, signifying how one can rise above his or her own turmoil by comparing themselves to the grand buildings rising above the entire city. The concept harkens back to her 2011 '[[Skyscraper (song)
column23: Skyscraper]]' single, where she boldly claims in the chorus, 'I will be rising from the ground/ Like a skyscraper.'\"<ref name=\"billboard_9331846\">{{cite web
column25: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Lyric Video: Watch

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Layla McMurtrie of ''[[The Eastern Echo]]'' called \"I Love Me\" \"a more fun and lighthearted song\" as a follow-up to Lovato's \"powerful Grammy performance\"  and that \"unlike her past two soft, emotional singles '[[Anyone (Demi Lovato song)
column3: Sober]],' this new song is more of a fun radio pop-hit.\" McMurtie continued with praise for the song's \"super heartfelt and raw\" lyrics, which she deemed as \"containing a meaningful message and good vibes\" and that \"I Love Me\" is \"an empowering and perfect beginning to Women's History Month\" because it \"presents a strong and independent woman who has grown drastically as both an artist and an individual.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Demi Lovato shows strength and confidence in new music video for \"I Love Me\"

column3: title=Demi Lovato is Victorious on New Single \"I Love Me\": Stream
column8: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"Vulture\"/> On March 5, 2020, Lovato released a 30-second teaser of the music video on digital platforms.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Demi Lovato divulga teaser do clipe de \"I Love Me\" e web reage
column16: date=March 2020}} It premiered on [[MTV Live (TV network)
column17: MTV Live]] on March 6, 2020, and was later uploaded to [[YouTube]].<ref name=\"USAToday\">{{cite web
column19: title='I'm my own worst critic': Demi Lovato confronts demons in new single 'I Love Me' Gary Dinges USA TODAY
column24: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> It amassed 5.8 million views on YouTube in its first 24 hours available on the platform.<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=All You Need Is Self-Love: The Wave of Wellness Songs Explained

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Lovato said the video was by far the \"most emotional\" for her to shoot and explained that it was important to add \"special [[Easter egg (media)
19th-century German pianist and composer: easter eggs]]\" that represented certain times and incidents in her life.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Demi Lovato on Instagram: \"This video was so special to me.. @hannahluxdavis absolutely killed this. It was important for me to add special easter eggs that represent...\"

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In the first scene, three versions of Lovato appear in a house, with two of them fighting each other. The other one, referred to as \"[[Zen]] Demi\" by both [[MTV News]]' Madeline Roth and [[Yahoo! Music]]'s Suzy Byrne, is dressed in white and trying to meditate.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato reflects on overdose, sings about her battle with her body image in 'I Love Me' video
column8: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> This scene parallels the line \"I'm a black belt when I'm beating up on myself\".<ref name=\"USAToday\"/> Wran Graves of ''[[Consequence of Sound]]'' opined it was \"dramatization of depression\".<ref name=\"CoS\"/> Olivia Singh of ''[[Insider Inc.#Websites
column9: Insider]]'' said the fight was a reference to Lovato's \"personal battles with her demons\" as well as her skills in [[mixed martial arts]].<ref name=\"Insider\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Later, Lovato gets out of the house wearing a red jacket and walking across the fictional \"I Love Me St.\" in [[New York City]], where multiple references to her past appear are shown.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/> While in the street, a blonde woman appears with two daughters dressed in 1990s clothing and taking them to an acting audition.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref>{{cite web
column3: title=El poderoso videoclip I Love Me de Demi Lovato muestra su viaje a la sobriedad
column9: language=es}}</ref> This represents Lovato herself at a young age with her mother Dianna De La Garza and sister Dallas Lovato, with the former tweeting, \"I feel like I was looking for an audition address [...] my [[doppelgänger]] is beautiful!\".<ref name=\"Insider\">{{cite web
column11: title=Demi Lovato's new music video is packed with hidden references. Here's every detail you may have missed.
column17: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> Later, a woman wearing a black bodysuit, sunglasses and short hair accompanied by bodyguards is depicted walking in the street. The woman references Lovato herself while promoting her 2015 studio album ''[[Confident (album)
column18: Confident]]'' on the [[Future Now Tour]].<ref name=\"Insider\"/><ref name=\"ET\">{{cite web
column20: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Music Video References Overdose, Jonas Brothers and Wilmer Valderrama
column25: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> In the next scene, Lovato passes by and smiles to a young girl holding a microphone and surrounded by three boys, whose looks and outfits resemble the characters that Lovato and the [[Jonas Brothers]] played in the 2008 [[Disney Channel]] film ''[[Camp Rock]]''.<ref name=\"Insider\" /><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/><ref name=\"ET\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: As she keeps on walking, Lovato passes by three men in golden jackets, to whom she smiles and [[cut-eye
19th-century German pianist and composer: cuts her eyes]] to.<ref name=\"Insider\"/> Desiree Murphy of ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' opined the three men were a reference to the Jonas Brothers, whom Lovato has worked with on different acting and music projects.<ref name=\"ET\"/> On the other hand, Singh wrote the scene represented Lovato \"being happy about the good times they shared, but also accepting that they've gone on separate paths\".<ref name=\"Insider\"/> The singer later walks past an ambulance which is assisting a woman on a stretcher, putting her hand on the woman's forehead. This referenced the [[Demi Lovato#2018 overdose
column3: July 2018 overdose]] that she suffered.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/><ref name=\"Insider\"/> Near the end of the music video, a bride and a groom run across the street, which referenced the engagement of Lovato's ex-boyfriend [[Wilmer Valderrama]].<ref name=\"Newsweek\">{{cite web
column5: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Video Shows Star Walking Past Overdose and Her Ex's New Wife
column10: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> The video ends with Lovato reuniting with two of her real-life friends, rapper [[Sirah (rapper)
column11: Sirah]] and actor Matthew Scott Montgomery.<ref name=\"Insider\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A lyric video of the song was released on March 10, 2020, which shows footage of the city of New York, including the original [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)
column4: title=Demi Lovato Shows Off Vintage New York City in 'I Love Me' Lyric Video
column9: accessdate=March 11, 2020}}</ref> Describing the visuals of the lyric video, ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column10: Billboard]]'' says Lovato \"uses vintage New York City shots to craft her self-love narrative\" and that she \"transports the viewers right into the hustle and bustle of the city, plopping them in the middle of foot traffic where it's easy to feel small.\"<ref name=\"billboard_9331846\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Upon release, the music video for \"I Love Me\" amassed 16.1 million views first week on YouTube, which placed it at number 22 on the global YouTube music videos chart. 4.9 million views of the 16.1 million global views were from the US, which ultimately placed it at number five on the US Music Videos Chart.<ref name=\"MV Headline\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato's \"I Love Me\" Lands At #22 On Global YouTube Music Videos Chart With 16.1 Million Views
column8: accessdate=March 16, 2020}}</ref> The song debuted number 18 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column9: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], becoming Lovato's ninth top 20 entry on the chart and her highest debut since the release of her song \"[[Heart Attack (Demi Lovato song)
column10: Heart Attack]]\" in 2013.  \"I Love Me\" was also the top-selling song of its release week, becoming Lovato's second number 1 on the Digital Song Sales Chart after her first number 1 with the release of \"[[Anyone (Demi Lovato song)
column13: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Is the Week's Top-Selling Song

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A music video for \"I Love Me\" was directed by [[Hannah Lux Davis]] and filmed in [[New York City]]. It was released on March 6, 2020, and depicts Lovato walking across a street with several references to moments in her career and personal life. It has charted within the top 20 in Hungary, Scotland, and the United States as well as the top 30 in Canada and Ireland.
\"I Love Me\" was written by [[Demi Lovato]] alongside [[Anne-Marie (singer)
column3: Sean Douglas]], Alex Niceforo, Keith Sorrells and [[Oak Felder
column4: Warren \"Oak\" Felder]] and produced by the latter three.<ref name=\"Tidal\">{{cite web
column6: title=I Love Me / Demi Lovato – Credits
column9: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> According to Anne-Marie, she co-wrote the song with other songwriters in 2019 before Lovato heard it and recorded it.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Anne-Marie Praises Demi Lovato For New Song 'I Love Me' – Which She Helped Write
column15: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> During an interview with [[Ellen DeGeneres]], Lovato described the track as \"fun and lighthearted\" that had a \"positive, upbeat message\".<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Did Demi Lovato Call Out Wilmer Valderrama In New Music Video?

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: On March 2, 2020, she announced through her [[Instagram]] that her upcoming new single \"I Love Me\" would be released four days later, attaching the cover art to the post.<ref name=\"Teen Vogue\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato Announces New Song \"I Love Me\"
column8: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> The artwork is a blurry picture of Lovato wearing a red jacket on a city street with the title of the single in the left upper corner.<ref name=\"Teen Vogue\"/> Lovato had previously used the title of the single as a hashtag for another Instagram picture on February 24.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Demi Lovato to release new song 'I Love Me' on Friday

column23: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> \"I Love Me\" was released on March 6, 2020, on both [[Music download
column25: streaming]] platforms,<ref name=\"BBrel\"/> as the [[lead single]] from her upcoming seventh studio album.<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Demi Lovato Says Her Self-Care Routine Involves a Lot of 'Aromatherapy, Listening to Music and Crying'
column33: limited edition]] alternative cover signed CD singles of the song were made available for purchase for twenty-four hours via Lovato's official online store,<ref>{{Cite tweet
column35: title=Signed #ILoveMe CDs Available for 24 hours only https://DemiLovato.lnk.to/Shop pic.twitter.com/OMpITk1t5J
column38: accessdate=March 13, 2020}}</ref> On March 12, vinyls with a different alternative cover were released for approximately four hours.<ref>{{Cite tweet

column20: title=First Stream: New Music From Megan Thee Stallion, Lil Uzi Vert, Demi Lovato & More

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In an interview with [[Apple Music]]'s Hanuman Welch, Lovato said \"I Love Me\" talked about \"loving yourself\", adding, \"It's an anthem, and it talks about how hard we are on ourselves and this, the negative self-talk. You know, how easily we can listen to that. But when is loving yourself gonna be enough?\".<ref name=\"ETO\"/> During ''[[the Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' she explained the title of the song, saying, \"We are good by ourselves. We don't need a partner, we don't need, like, substance. We're good.\"<ref name=\"ETO\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato \"Taking a Little Bit More Time\" Working on Her New Album Amid Comeback
column8: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> During the first verse, Lovato sings about her past problems with eating disorders and body image, \"Can't see what I am, I just see what I'm not / I'm guilty 'bout everything that I eat (every single day)\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Demi Lovato's New Single \"I Love Me\" Is the Self-Love Anthem We Need but Don't Deserve
column18: title=Demi Lovato Gets Extremely Personal About Her Past Struggles in the Lyrics to Her New Song 'I Love Me'

19th-century German pianist and composer: Billboard]]'' said the song was about Lovato's \"battle with her mental health\", as exemplified in the chorus, \"Oh, why do I compare myself to everyone?/ And I always got my finger on the self-destruct/ I wonder when I love me is enough\".<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The 13 Best Things That Happened in Music This Week (March 6)
column9: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Rania Aniftos of the same magazine described \"I Love Me\" as a \"self-love\" and \"empowering\" song.<ref name=\"BBrel\">{{cite web
column11: title=Demi Lovato Drops Self-Love Single 'I Love Me' & Video: Watch
column16: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Marcus Jones of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' said the track focused on \"self-love\" and noted it was more upbeat than Lovato's previous single, \"Anyone\".<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Demi Lovato declares 'I Love Me' in empowering new anthem: Watch the video
column23: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> Kelly Wynne of ''[[Newsweek]]'' also deemed it as a \"ode to self and the powers each person holds as an individual.\"<ref name=\"Newsweek\"/>

19th-century German pianist and composer: Vulture]]'' deemed \"I Love Me\" as a \"rousing, introspective pop song about self-love and self-doubt\".<ref name=\"Vulture\"/> Mike Nied of ''[[Idolator (website)
column3: Idolator]]'' called the song a \"bop with a very important message\", adding it \"packs just as much personality as '[[Sorry Not Sorry (Demi Lovato song)
column4: Sorry Not Sorry]]' but feels more elevated\".<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Is An Essential Self-Empowerment Anthem
column12: accessdate=March 8, 2020}}</ref> Claire Shaffer and Althea Legaspi of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' praised the music video in an article entitled \"Demi Lovato Confidently Showcases 'I Love Me' is Enough in New Music Video\", saying \"Her confident stride and dancing showcases the resilience that's found in learning to love one's self.\"<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Demi Lovato Confidently Showcases 'I Love Me' is Enough in New Video
column22: Billboard]]'', referring to the lyric video that depicts vintage New York City, said that \"The way Lovato picks herself up in the song and transmits that uplifting message to her fans is seen in the low-angle skyscraper shots, signifying how one can rise above his or her own turmoil by comparing themselves to the grand buildings rising above the entire city. The concept harkens back to her 2011 '[[Skyscraper (song)
column23: Skyscraper]]' single, where she boldly claims in the chorus, 'I will be rising from the ground/ Like a skyscraper.'\"<ref name=\"billboard_9331846\">{{cite web
column25: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Lyric Video: Watch

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Layla McMurtrie of ''[[The Eastern Echo]]'' called \"I Love Me\" \"a more fun and lighthearted song\" as a follow-up to Lovato's \"powerful Grammy performance\"  and that \"unlike her past two soft, emotional singles '[[Anyone (Demi Lovato song)
column3: Sober]],' this new song is more of a fun radio pop-hit.\" McMurtie continued with praise for the song's \"super heartfelt and raw\" lyrics, which she deemed as \"containing a meaningful message and good vibes\" and that \"I Love Me\" is \"an empowering and perfect beginning to Women's History Month\" because it \"presents a strong and independent woman who has grown drastically as both an artist and an individual.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Demi Lovato shows strength and confidence in new music video for \"I Love Me\"

column3: title=Demi Lovato is Victorious on New Single \"I Love Me\": Stream

column16: date=March 2020}} It premiered on [[MTV Live (TV network)
column17: MTV Live]] on March 6, 2020, and was later uploaded to [[YouTube]].<ref name=\"USAToday\">{{cite web
