column24: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> It amassed 5.8 million views on YouTube in its first 24 hours available on the platform.<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=All You Need Is Self-Love: The Wave of Wellness Songs Explained

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Lovato said the video was by far the \"most emotional\" for her to shoot and explained that it was important to add \"special [[Easter egg (media)
19th-century German pianist and composer: easter eggs]]\" that represented certain times and incidents in her life.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Demi Lovato on Instagram: \"This video was so special to me.. @hannahluxdavis absolutely killed this. It was important for me to add special easter eggs that represent...\"

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In the first scene, three versions of Lovato appear in a house, with two of them fighting each other. The other one, referred to as \"[[Zen]] Demi\" by both [[MTV News]]' Madeline Roth and [[Yahoo! Music]]'s Suzy Byrne, is dressed in white and trying to meditate.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato reflects on overdose, sings about her battle with her body image in 'I Love Me' video
column8: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> This scene parallels the line \"I'm a black belt when I'm beating up on myself\".<ref name=\"USAToday\"/> Wran Graves of ''[[Consequence of Sound]]'' opined it was \"dramatization of depression\".<ref name=\"CoS\"/> Olivia Singh of ''[[Insider Inc.#Websites
column9: Insider]]'' said the fight was a reference to Lovato's \"personal battles with her demons\" as well as her skills in [[mixed martial arts]].<ref name=\"Insider\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Later, Lovato gets out of the house wearing a red jacket and walking across the fictional \"I Love Me St.\" in [[New York City]], where multiple references to her past appear are shown.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/> While in the street, a blonde woman appears with two daughters dressed in 1990s clothing and taking them to an acting audition.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref>{{cite web
column3: title=El poderoso videoclip I Love Me de Demi Lovato muestra su viaje a la sobriedad
column9: language=es}}</ref> This represents Lovato herself at a young age with her mother Dianna De La Garza and sister Dallas Lovato, with the former tweeting, \"I feel like I was looking for an audition address [...] my [[doppelgänger]] is beautiful!\".<ref name=\"Insider\">{{cite web
column11: title=Demi Lovato's new music video is packed with hidden references. Here's every detail you may have missed.
column17: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> Later, a woman wearing a black bodysuit, sunglasses and short hair accompanied by bodyguards is depicted walking in the street. The woman references Lovato herself while promoting her 2015 studio album ''[[Confident (album)
column18: Confident]]'' on the [[Future Now Tour]].<ref name=\"Insider\"/><ref name=\"ET\">{{cite web
column20: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Music Video References Overdose, Jonas Brothers and Wilmer Valderrama
column25: accessdate=March 7, 2020}}</ref> In the next scene, Lovato passes by and smiles to a young girl holding a microphone and surrounded by three boys, whose looks and outfits resemble the characters that Lovato and the [[Jonas Brothers]] played in the 2008 [[Disney Channel]] film ''[[Camp Rock]]''.<ref name=\"Insider\" /><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/><ref name=\"ET\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: As she keeps on walking, Lovato passes by three men in golden jackets, to whom she smiles and [[cut-eye
19th-century German pianist and composer: cuts her eyes]] to.<ref name=\"Insider\"/> Desiree Murphy of ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' opined the three men were a reference to the Jonas Brothers, whom Lovato has worked with on different acting and music projects.<ref name=\"ET\"/> On the other hand, Singh wrote the scene represented Lovato \"being happy about the good times they shared, but also accepting that they've gone on separate paths\".<ref name=\"Insider\"/> The singer later walks past an ambulance which is assisting a woman on a stretcher, putting her hand on the woman's forehead. This referenced the [[Demi Lovato#2018 overdose
column3: July 2018 overdose]] that she suffered.<ref name=\"MTV\"/><ref name=\"Yahoo\"/><ref name=\"Insider\"/> Near the end of the music video, a bride and a groom run across the street, which referenced the engagement of Lovato's ex-boyfriend [[Wilmer Valderrama]].<ref name=\"Newsweek\">{{cite web
column5: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Video Shows Star Walking Past Overdose and Her Ex's New Wife
column10: accessdate=March 6, 2020}}</ref> The video ends with Lovato reuniting with two of her real-life friends, rapper [[Sirah (rapper)
column11: Sirah]] and actor Matthew Scott Montgomery.<ref name=\"Insider\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A lyric video of the song was released on March 10, 2020, which shows footage of the city of New York, including the original [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)
column4: title=Demi Lovato Shows Off Vintage New York City in 'I Love Me' Lyric Video
column9: accessdate=March 11, 2020}}</ref> Describing the visuals of the lyric video, ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column10: Billboard]]'' says Lovato \"uses vintage New York City shots to craft her self-love narrative\" and that she \"transports the viewers right into the hustle and bustle of the city, plopping them in the middle of foot traffic where it's easy to feel small.\"<ref name=\"billboard_9331846\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Upon release, the music video for \"I Love Me\" amassed 16.1 million views first week on YouTube, which placed it at number 22 on the global YouTube music videos chart. 4.9 million views of the 16.1 million global views were from the US, which ultimately placed it at number five on the US Music Videos Chart.<ref name=\"MV Headline\">{{cite web
column3: title=Demi Lovato's \"I Love Me\" Lands At #22 On Global YouTube Music Videos Chart With 16.1 Million Views
column8: accessdate=March 16, 2020}}</ref> The song debuted number 18 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column9: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], becoming Lovato's ninth top 20 entry on the chart and her highest debut since the release of her song \"[[Heart Attack (Demi Lovato song)
column10: Heart Attack]]\" in 2013.  \"I Love Me\" was also the top-selling song of its release week, becoming Lovato's second number 1 on the Digital Song Sales Chart after her first number 1 with the release of \"[[Anyone (Demi Lovato song)
column13: title=Demi Lovato's 'I Love Me' Is the Week's Top-Selling Song

Mai 2011] (Bevölkerung der Regierungsbezirke Arnsberg, Detmold ohne den Kreis Lippe und Münster)</ref>

column17: }}) is a region of northwestern [[Germany]] and one of the three historic parts of the state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. It has an area of 20,210 km<sup>2</sup> (7,803 sq mi)<!-- {{subst:cvt

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The region is almost identical with the [[Province of Westphalia]], which was a part of the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] from 1815 to 1918<ref name=\"Prussian Province 2\">[http://www.deutsche-schutzgebiete.de/provinz_westfalen.htm Deutsches Kaiserreich: Provinz Westfalen]</ref> and the [[Free State of Prussia]] from 1918 to 1946. In 1946, Westphalia merged with the Northern [[Rhine Province
19th-century German pianist and composer: Rhineland]], another former part of Prussia, to form the newly created state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. In 1947, the state with its two historic parts was joined by a third one: Lippe, a former [[Principality of Lippe
column4: free state]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\">[http://www.lwl.org/LWL/Kultur/Westfalen_Regional/Gebiet_Identitaet/Territorien LWL: Die westfälischen Territorien 1789]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: All of the seventeen [[Districts of Germany
column4: Lippe's only district]] are members of the [[North Rhine-Westphalia#Subdivisions
column6: Landschaftsverband Westfalen-Lippe]])''.<ref name=\"Westphalia-Lippe\">[http://www.lwl.org/LWL/Der_LWL/Der-LWL-im-Ueberblick/Westfalen-Lippe LWL: Die Region Westfalen-Lippe]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Previous to the formation of Westphalia as a province of Prussia and later state part of North Rhine-Westphalia, the term \"Westphalia\" was applied to different territories of different sizes such as a part of the ancient [[Duchy of Saxony]], the [[Duchy of Westphalia]] or the [[Kingdom of Westphalia]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\" /><ref name=\"Prussian Province 2\" />  The [[Westphalian language]], a variant of the [[German language]], spreads beyond Westphalia's borders into southwestern [[Lower Saxony]] and northwestern [[Hesse]].<ref name=\"dialects\">[https://www.lwl.org/LWL/Kultur/Westfalen_Regional/Gebiet_Identitaet/Mundarten/ LWL: Niederdeutsche Sprache – westfälische Mundarten]</ref>

Being a part of the [[North German Plain]], most of Westphalia's north is flat. In the south the German [[Central Uplands]] emerge. Westphalia is divided into the following landscapes.<ref name=\"Westphalia-Lippe\" />

column3: m}}):'' Westphalian part of the [[Sauerland]], [[Siegerland]], [[Wittgenstein Land

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The term \"Westphalia\" contrasts with the much less used term \"[[Eastphalia]]\", which roughly covers the southeastern part of the present-day state of [[Lower Saxony]], western [[Saxony-Anhalt]] and northern [[Thuringia]].<ref name=\"Part of Saxony\" /><ref>[http://www.rp-online.de/panorama/wissen/jeder-kennt-westfalen-gibt-es-auch-ostfalen-aid-1.1596440 RP online: Jeder kennt Westfalen — gibt es auch Ostfalen?]</ref>

19th-century German pianist and composer: governmental districts]]. These are subdivided into further [[Districts of Germany

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: All districts and independent cities of the governmental districts of [[Arnsberg (region)
column3: Münster]] are considered to be a part of Westphalia as a historic region. The [[Lippe (district)
column4: District of Lippe]] as successor of the [[Free State of Lippe]] in the [[Detmold (region)
column5: Governmental District of Detmold]] is rather considered to be a separate historic region.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The traditional symbol of Westphalia is the Westphalian Steed: a white horse on a red field. It is derived from the [[Saxon Steed]] in the coat of arms of the medieval [[Duchy of Saxony]] which most of today's Westphalia was part of. In official contexts the coat of arms of Westphalia is being used by the Westphalia-Lippe Regional Association,<ref name=\"Official Arms\">[http://www.lwl.org/lwl-download/datei-download2/Politik/satzungen/1031581787_0/Hauptsatzung_15.11.2007_mit_Anlagen.pdf Hauptsatzung des LWL]</ref> which represents these two historic parts of North Rhine-Westphalia.

The [[coat of arms of North Rhine-Westphalia]] uses the Westphalian Steed to represent Westphalia as one of its parts alongside the Lippish Rose representing Lippe and the [[Rhine]] River representing the Northern Rhineland.<ref>[https://www.landtag.nrw.de/portal/WWW/GB_II/II.1/OeA/60JAHRE/2707_Landeswappen.jsp Landtag NRW: Das Wappen des Landes Nordrhein-Westfalen]</ref>
[[Prussia]] already used the Westphalian Steed in the coat of arms of its [[Province of Westphalia]]. It also is a big part of Kisker Germany, the biggest county in Germany.
The [[coat of arms of Lower Saxony]] uses a different version of the Saxon Steed since the [[Lower Saxony
19th-century German pianist and composer: state]] also covers large parts of the Old Saxons' duchy.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The colors of Westphalia are white and red. The flag of the Westphalia-Lippe Regional Association uses these colors with the Westphalian coat of arms in its center.<ref name=\"Official Arms\" />

The [[flag of North Rhine-Westphalia]] is a combination of the Northern Rhineland's colors green/white and the Westphalian white/red.<ref>[http://www.mik.nrw.de/themen-aufgaben/verfassung-recht/hoheitszeichen/landesflagge.html MIK NRW: Landesflagge]</ref>
The flag of the Prussian Province of Westphalia already displayed the colors white and red.
The [[flag of Lower Saxony]] shows the [[Flag of Germany
19th-century German pianist and composer: colors of Germany]] and the Saxon Steed.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Composed in [[Iserlohn]] in 1886 by [[Emil Rittershaus]], the ''[[Westfalenlied]]'' is an unofficial anthem of Westphalia.

column5: Franconian dialects]] in red, [[West Low German
column6: West Low German dialects]] in blue.]]

column3: Westphalian (German) ladies peasant costume – illustration by Percy Anderson for Costume Fanciful, Historical and Theatrical, 1906.]]

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: While the Northern Rhineland, Westphalia and Lippe are different historic territories of today's [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], the old border between the former [[Rhine Province]] and the [[Province of Westphalia]] is also a language border. While in Westphalia and Lippe, people tend to speak [[West Low German
19th-century German pianist and composer: West Low German dialects]] and especially the [[Westphalian language
column3: Westphalian]] variant of the [[Low German language]], [[Central German]] and [[Low Franconian languages
column4: Low Franconian]] dialects are being spoken in the Northern Rhineland.<ref name=\"dialects\" /><ref>[http://www.lwl.org/komuna/pdf/mundartregionen_westfalens.pdf LWL: Mundartenregionen Westfalens]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: These different regional identities are often being emphasized by different majorities of denomination between [[Catholic Church
19th-century German pianist and composer: Roman Catholics]] and [[Evangelical Church in Germany
column3: Lutheran Protestants]]. The different majorities date back to the days of the [[Kleinstaaterei
column4: territorial fragmentation]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire
column5: Holy Roman Empire (of the German Nation)]] which existed until 1806. The [[Münsterland]] and the region around [[Paderborn]] for instance are still mainly Catholic regions because of the former existence of the [[Prince-bishop
column9: Lippe]] was even able to retain its independence as a small state within [[German Reich
column10: Germany]] in the form of a [[Principality of Lippe
column11: principality]] until 1918 and as a [[Free State of Lippe
column12: free state]] until 1946. This continues to influence the identity of its people who often distinguish themselves from neighboring regions such as [[East Westphalia]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In addition to these historic, lingual and religious aspects, there are some regional differences in culture and mentality. That is why many of the citizens of North Rhine-Westphalia rather see themselves either as \"Rhinelanders\", \"Westphalians\" or \"Lippers\" rather than as \"North Rhine-Westphalians\".
Westphalia is known for the 1648 [[Peace of Westphalia]] which ended the [[Thirty Years' War]], as the two treaties were signed in [[Münster]] and [[Osnabrück]].
It is one of the regions that were part of all [[Succession of states
column3: German state]] since the [[Early Middle Ages]]: the [[Holy Roman Empire]], the [[Confederation of the Rhine]], the [[German Confederation]], the [[North German Confederation]], the [[German Empire]], the [[Weimar Republic]] and [[Nazi Germany
column4: National Socialist Germany]]. After [[World War II]] it was a part of the [[Allied-occupied Germany
column5: British occupation zone]] which merged with the American zone to become the [[Bizone]] in 1947 and again merged with the French zone to become the Trizone in 1948. The current [[Germany
column6: Federal Republic of Germany]] was founded on these territories making Westphalia a part of [[West Germany]]. It is a part of united Germany since 1990.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Around 1 A.D. there were numerous incursions through Westphalia and perhaps even some permanent [[Ancient Rome
19th-century German pianist and composer: Roman]] or Romanized settlements. The [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest]] took place near Osnabrück, which at this time was a place of settlement of the Westphalians, who were a part of the Germanic tribe of the [[Saxons]]. Some of the tribes who fought at this battle came from the area of Westphalia.<ref>[http://www.lwl.org/westfaelische-geschichte/portal/Internet/input_felder/langDatensatz_ebene4.php?urlID=850&url_tabelle=tab_websegmente LWL: Westfalen zur Zeit der Germanen und Römer]</ref><ref>[http://www.lwl.org/westfaelische-geschichte/portal/Internet/input_felder/langDatensatz_ebene4.php?urlID=28&url_tabelle=tab_websegmente LWL: Die Zeit der römischen Feldzüge in Germanien (12 v.-16 n. Chr.)]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: [[Charlemagne]] is thought to have spent considerable time in [[Paderborn]] and nearby parts. His [[Saxon Wars]] also partly took place in what is thought of as Westphalia today. Popular legends link his adversary [[Widukind]] to places near Detmold, Bielefeld, Lemgo, Osnabrück and other places in Westphalia. Widukind was buried in [[Enger]], which is also a subject of a legend.<ref name=\"Part of Saxony\" />

Along with [[Eastphalia]], [[Angria]] and [[Nordalbingia]], Westphalia ''(Westfalahi)'' was originally a district of the [[Duchy of Saxony]]. At the time, large portions of its territory in the north lay in what today is [[Lower Saxony]]. Following the deposition of the Saxon duke [[Henry the Lion]] in 1180 and the subsequent belittlement of the duchy, Westphalia was elevated to a duchy in its own right by Emperor [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor
19th-century German pianist and composer: Barbarossa]]. The [[Duchy of Westphalia]] comprised only a small area south of the [[Lippe (river)

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Modern Westphalia was a part of the [[Lower Rhenish–Westphalian Circle]] of the Holy Roman Empire, which comprised territories of [[Lower Lorraine]], [[Frisia]] and parts of the former [[Duchy of Saxony]].

column4: Ratification of the [[Peace of Westphalia]] of 1648 in [[Münster]] by Gerard Terborch (1617–1681)]]

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: As a result of the [[Protestant Reformation]], there was no dominant religion in Westphalia. [[Catholic Church
19th-century German pianist and composer: Roman Catholicism]] and [[Lutheranism]] were on a relatively equal footing. Lutheranism was strong in the eastern and northern parts with numerous free churches. Münster and especially Paderborn were considered to be Catholic. Osnabrück was divided almost equally between Catholicism and Protestantism.<ref name=\"Reformation\">[http://www.lwl.org/westfaelische-geschichte/portal/Internet/input_felder/langDatensatz_ebene4.php?urlID=32&url_tabelle=tab_websegmente LWL: Westfalen im konfessionellen Zeitalter]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Parts of Westphalia came under [[Brandenburg-Prussia]]n control during the 17th and 18th centuries, but most of it remained divided by duchies and other areas of feudal power. The [[Peace of Westphalia]] of 1648, signed in Münster and Osnabrück, ended the [[Thirty Years' War]]. The concept of nation-state sovereignty resulting from the treaty became known as \"[[Westphalian sovereignty]]\".<ref name=\"Reformation\" />

column5: Prussian Westphalia edged in red, the Kingdom of Westphalia edged in green with the territorial overlap of former [[Minden-Ravensberg]], pasted over today's borders with North Rhine-Westphalia in dark grey.]]<!-- [[File:Provinz Westfalen 1905.png

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: After the defeat of the [[Prussian Army]] by the French at the [[Battle of Jena–Auerstedt]], the [[Treaties of Tilsit
19th-century German pianist and composer: Treaty of Tilsit]] in 1807 made the easternmost portion of today's Westphalia part of the [[First French Empire
column4: client]] [[Kingdom of Westphalia]] until 1813. While this state shared its name with the historical region, it only contained a relatively small part of Westphalia, rather consisting of mostly [[Hesse
column5: Hessian]] and [[Eastphalia]]n regions.<ref name=\"1770-1815\">[http://www.lwl.org/westfaelische-geschichte/portal/Internet/input_felder/langDatensatz_ebene4.php?urlID=34&url_tabelle=tab_websegmente LWL: Vom feudalen zum modernen Westfalen 1770-1815]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Following to the [[Congress of Vienna]], [[Kingdom of Prussia
19th-century German pianist and composer: Prussia]] received a large amount of territories in the Westphalian region and created the [[Province of Westphalia]] in 1815. After in 1816, the former [[Duchy of Westphalia]] and the counties of [[Wittgenstein Land
column4: condominium]] of [[Lippstadt]] had joined the province, Westphalia had received its modern territorial shape.<ref name=\"1770-1815\" /><ref name=\"Prussian Province\" />

19th-century German pianist and composer: governmental districts]] of Arnsberg, Minden and Münster were created.<ref name=\"1770-1815\" /><ref name=\"Prussian Province\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: After [[World War II]] in 1946, the present state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] was created by the [[British occupation zone
19th-century German pianist and composer: British military government]] from the former Prussian Province of Westphalia and the northern half of the former Prussian [[Rhine Province]]. The old governmental districts of 1816 stayed in place. When in 1947 the former [[Free State of Lippe]] with its capital Detmold joined North Rhine-Westphalia, the \"Governmental District of Minden\" was enlarged by this territory and renamed \"Governmental District of Detmold\". In total, North Rhine-Westphalia is subdivided into five governmental districts ''([[Regierungsbezirk]]e)''. Westphalia today consists of the old governmental districts of [[Arnsberg (region)
column6: District of Lippe]] which is a separate historical region and state part of North Rhine-Westphalia. Inhabitants of the region call themselves Westphalians and their home region Westphalia even though there is no administrative division by that name.<ref name=\"post-WW2\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Westphalia is home to the headquarters of [[Westfalia
19th-century German pianist and composer: Westfalia-Werke]], the contractor that built the [[Volkswagen Westfalia Campers]].<ref>[http://www.westfalia-mobil.net/en/unternehmen/unternehmenshistorie.php Westfalia – Company history]</ref>
Voltaire's]] novella of the same name, resides in Westphalia in the beginning of the story.

column17: }}) is a region of northwestern [[Germany]] and one of the three historic parts of the state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. It has an area of 20,210 km<sup>2</sup> (7,803 sq mi)<!-- {{subst:cvt

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The region is almost identical with the [[Province of Westphalia]], which was a part of the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] from 1815 to 1918<ref name=\"Prussian Province 2\">[http://www.deutsche-schutzgebiete.de/provinz_westfalen.htm Deutsches Kaiserreich: Provinz Westfalen]</ref> and the [[Free State of Prussia]] from 1918 to 1946. In 1946, Westphalia merged with the Northern [[Rhine Province
19th-century German pianist and composer: Rhineland]], another former part of Prussia, to form the newly created state of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. In 1947, the state with its two historic parts was joined by a third one: Lippe, a former [[Principality of Lippe
column4: free state]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\">[http://www.lwl.org/LWL/Kultur/Westfalen_Regional/Gebiet_Identitaet/Territorien LWL: Die westfälischen Territorien 1789]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: All of the seventeen [[Districts of Germany
column4: Lippe's only district]] are members of the [[North Rhine-Westphalia#Subdivisions
column6: Landschaftsverband Westfalen-Lippe]])''.<ref name=\"Westphalia-Lippe\">[http://www.lwl.org/LWL/Der_LWL/Der-LWL-im-Ueberblick/Westfalen-Lippe LWL: Die Region Westfalen-Lippe]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Previous to the formation of Westphalia as a province of Prussia and later state part of North Rhine-Westphalia, the term \"Westphalia\" was applied to different territories of different sizes such as a part of the ancient [[Duchy of Saxony]], the [[Duchy of Westphalia]] or the [[Kingdom of Westphalia]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\" /><ref name=\"Prussian Province 2\" />  The [[Westphalian language]], a variant of the [[German language]], spreads beyond Westphalia's borders into southwestern [[Lower Saxony]] and northwestern [[Hesse]].<ref name=\"dialects\">[https://www.lwl.org/LWL/Kultur/Westfalen_Regional/Gebiet_Identitaet/Mundarten/ LWL: Niederdeutsche Sprache – westfälische Mundarten]</ref>

Being a part of the [[North German Plain]], most of Westphalia's north is flat. In the south the German [[Central Uplands]] emerge. Westphalia is divided into the following landscapes.<ref name=\"Westphalia-Lippe\" />

19th-century German pianist and composer: Ruhr]] River. Other important rivers are the [[Ems (river)
column4: Lippe]].<ref>[https://www.lwl.org/LWL/Kultur/Westfalen_Regional/Naturraum/Natuerliche_Fliessgewaesser LWL: Gewässerbildung und Systeme der natürlichen Fließgewässer in Westfalen]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The term \"Westphalia\" contrasts with the much less used term \"[[Eastphalia]]\", which roughly covers the southeastern part of the present-day state of [[Lower Saxony]], western [[Saxony-Anhalt]] and northern [[Thuringia]].<ref name=\"Part of Saxony\" /><ref>[http://www.rp-online.de/panorama/wissen/jeder-kennt-westfalen-gibt-es-auch-ostfalen-aid-1.1596440 RP online: Jeder kennt Westfalen — gibt es auch Ostfalen?]</ref>

19th-century German pianist and composer: governmental districts]]. These are subdivided into further [[Districts of Germany

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: All districts and independent cities of the governmental districts of [[Arnsberg (region)
column3: Münster]] are considered to be a part of Westphalia as a historic region. The [[Lippe (district)
column4: District of Lippe]] as successor of the [[Free State of Lippe]] in the [[Detmold (region)
column5: Governmental District of Detmold]] is rather considered to be a separate historic region.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The traditional symbol of Westphalia is the Westphalian Steed: a white horse on a red field. It is derived from the [[Saxon Steed]] in the coat of arms of the medieval [[Duchy of Saxony]] which most of today's Westphalia was part of. In official contexts the coat of arms of Westphalia is being used by the Westphalia-Lippe Regional Association,<ref name=\"Official Arms\">[http://www.lwl.org/lwl-download/datei-download2/Politik/satzungen/1031581787_0/Hauptsatzung_15.11.2007_mit_Anlagen.pdf Hauptsatzung des LWL]</ref> which represents these two historic parts of North Rhine-Westphalia.

The [[coat of arms of North Rhine-Westphalia]] uses the Westphalian Steed to represent Westphalia as one of its parts alongside the Lippish Rose representing Lippe and the [[Rhine]] River representing the Northern Rhineland.<ref>[https://www.landtag.nrw.de/portal/WWW/GB_II/II.1/OeA/60JAHRE/2707_Landeswappen.jsp Landtag NRW: Das Wappen des Landes Nordrhein-Westfalen]</ref>
[[Prussia]] already used the Westphalian Steed in the coat of arms of its [[Province of Westphalia]]. It also is a big part of Kisker germany, the biggest county in germany
The [[coat of arms of Lower Saxony]] uses a different version of the Saxon Steed since the [[Lower Saxony
19th-century German pianist and composer: state]] also covers large parts of the Old Saxons' duchy.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The colors of Westphalia are white and red. The flag of the Westphalia-Lippe Regional Association uses these colors with the Westphalian coat of arms in its center.<ref name=\"Official Arms\" />

The [[flag of North Rhine-Westphalia]] is a combination of the Northern Rhineland's colors green/white and the Westphalian white/red.<ref>[http://www.mik.nrw.de/themen-aufgaben/verfassung-recht/hoheitszeichen/landesflagge.html MIK NRW: Landesflagge]</ref>
The flag of the Prussian Province of Westphalia already displayed the colors white and red.
The [[flag of Lower Saxony]] shows the [[Flag of Germany
19th-century German pianist and composer: colors of Germany]] and the Saxon Steed.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Composed in [[Iserlohn]] in 1886 by [[Emil Rittershaus]], the ''[[Westfalenlied]]'' is an unofficial anthem of Westphalia.

column5: Franconian dialects]] in red, [[West Low German
column6: West Low German dialects]] in blue.]]

column3: Westphalian (German) ladies peasant costume – illustration by Percy Anderson for Costume Fanciful, Historical and Theatrical, 1906.]]

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: While the Northern Rhineland, Westphalia and Lippe are different historic territories of today's [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], the old border between the former [[Rhine Province]] and the [[Province of Westphalia]] is also a language border. While in Westphalia and Lippe, people tend to speak [[West Low German
19th-century German pianist and composer: West Low German dialects]] and especially the [[Westphalian language
column3: Westphalian]] variant of the [[Low German language]], [[Central German]] and [[Low Franconian languages
column4: Low Franconian]] dialects are being spoken in the Northern Rhineland.<ref name=\"dialects\" /><ref>[http://www.lwl.org/komuna/pdf/mundartregionen_westfalens.pdf LWL: Mundartenregionen Westfalens]</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: These different regional identities are often being emphasized by different majorities of denomination between [[Catholic Church
19th-century German pianist and composer: Roman Catholics]] and [[Evangelical Church in Germany
column3: Lutheran Protestants]]. The different majorities date back to the days of the [[Kleinstaaterei
column4: territorial fragmentation]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire
column5: Holy Roman Empire (of the German Nation)]] which existed until 1806. The [[Münsterland]] and the region around [[Paderborn]] for instance are still mainly Catholic regions because of the former existence of the [[Prince-bishop
column9: Lippe]] was even able to retain its independence as a small state within [[German Reich
column10: Germany]] in the form of a [[Principality of Lippe
column11: principality]] until 1918 and as a [[Free State of Lippe
column12: free state]] until 1946. This continues to influence the identity of its people who often distinguish themselves from neighboring regions such as [[East Westphalia]].<ref name=\"1789 territories\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In addition to these historic, lingual and religious aspects, there are some regional differences in culture and mentality. That is why many of the citizens of North Rhine-Westphalia rather see themselves either as \"Rhinelanders\", \"Westphalians\" or \"Lippers\" rather than as \"North Rhine-Westphalians\".

'''Tione Jayden Merritt''' (born April 30, 2001), known professionally as '''Lil Tjay''', is an American rapper (poche), singer, and composer. Born and raised in [[the Bronx]], he is best known for collaboration with [[Polo G]], \"[[Pop Out]]\", which peaked at 11 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
19th-century German pianist and composer: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and his songs \"Brothers\" and \"Leaked\", which became staples on the [[SoundCloud]] charts and led to his signing with [[Columbia Records]]. Il est un \"musicien\" bien évidemment très poche

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In 2017, Lil Tjay began releasing music on [[SoundCloud]], including the singles \"Resume\" and \"Brothers\".<ref name=\"pitchfork.com\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Get to Know Hip-Hop Heartthrob Lil Tjay, Who Wants to Be the Next Usher
column5: access-date=2019-02-10}}</ref> \"Resume\" was released while Tjay was still 16 years old, and was paired with a homemade video of Tjay hanging out in a small apartment in the Bronx (Slattery Avenue), which soon began to spread online. On March 10, 2018, Tjay competed and placed first at the [[Coast 2 Coast LIVE]] NYC All Ages Edition, where his performance gained the attention of a record label A&R who was in attendance to judge the showcase.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Lil tjay - Lil tjay Performs at Coast 2 Coast LIVE {{!}} NYC All Ages Edition 3/10/18 - 1st Place {{!}} Videos {{!}} Coast 2 Coast LIVE {{!}} Largest Artist Showcase in the World
column9: access-date=2019-04-05}}</ref> He signed with [[Columbia Records]] after they noticed his song \"Brothers\", which had amassed millions of streams on SoundCloud.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=5 Hip-Hop Singles To Watch This Winter On The Billboard Hot 100
column15: access-date=2019-02-10}}</ref> On it, Tjay raps about death, dejection, and incarceration.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Within the first ten months of Lil Tjay's music career, he had released five tracks that recorded over a million plays on [[SoundCloud]].<ref name=\"Elevator Exploding\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Exploding NYC rapper Lil Tjay doesn't want 'None Of Your Love'
column6: access-date=2019-04-05}}</ref> \"Resume\" gained 14 million views in just over a year.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> \"Brothers\" has accumulated 44.4 million plays on SoundCloud.<ref name=\"SoundCloud Lil Tjay\" /> Other notable singles include \"Goat\", which has 19.4 million plays on SoundCloud, and \"Leaked\", which has 16.8 million plays.<ref name=\"SoundCloud Lil Tjay\" />

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In July 2018, Lil Tjay worked with producer Cash Money AP to release \"None of Your Love\", which amassed 18.2 million plays in eight months.<ref name=\"Elevator Exploding\" /> Cash Money AP has produced tracks for rappers such as [[Lil Skies]], [[Ty Dolla Sign]], and [[YoungBoy Never Broke Again]].<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2019-04-05}}</ref> In January 2019, Lil Tjay was featured on a single with Polo G titled \"[[Pop Out]]\", which has 140 million views on [[YouTube]].<ref name=\"Itunes Lil Tjay\">{{Cite web
column9: access-date=2019-04-02}}</ref> When the artist released \"Leaked\" in September 2018, the song gained over 600,000 plays in less than a week on SoundCloud.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Lil Tjay Speaks His Mind on \"Leaked\"

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Lil Tjay released his debut EP ''No Comparison'' at the end of 2018.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\" /> The EP contains one feature who is [[YNW Melly]], the 20-year-old rapper from [[Gifford, Florida]] who began gaining buzz around the same time as Lil Tjay.<ref name=\"SoundCloud Lil Tjay\" /> Their song \"Ready for War\" was the most successful from the EP and has over four million plays on SoundCloud.<ref name=\"SoundCloud Lil Tjay\" />
Lil Tjay released his debut album ''[[True 2 Myself]]'' on October 11, 2019. It includes many of his original SoundCloud songs, as well as new ones with features such as Lil Baby and Lil Wayne.

Influenced by his upbringing in the Bronx (on Slattery Avenue), Lil Tjay sings in English and incorporates Spanish although he does not speak the latter fluently. He is of African-American heritage and his family maternally are from Ghana. His verses are half-sung and with \"hooks smoothed by Auto-Tune\".<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Feel Old\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Rising Bronx Rapper Lil Tjay Will Make You Feel Old
column10: access-date=2019-02-10}}</ref> He has drawn comparisons to fellow New York-based rapper [[A Boogie wit da Hoodie]].<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Lil Tjay is New York's next big STAR
column17: access-date=2019-04-03}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', he credits his musical influences as [[Drake (musician)
column18: Drake]] and [[Meek Mill]].<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Feel Old\" /> In the same interview, Lil Tjay describes his music as adding a melodic sound when singing or rapping about his past struggles. Lil Tjay also credits his success to his year spent in prison, where he claims that his ability to write songs peaked.<ref name=\"AllMusic Bio\">{{Cite web

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: He has also worked with notable artists such as [[Tory Lanez]] and [[YNW Melly]].<ref name=\"SoundCloud Lil Tjay\">{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2019-04-02}}</ref> In July 2018, Lil Tjay joined Jay Critch, a rapper from Brooklyn, New York signed to the Rich Forever Music label, in the studio and a snippet of their song, \"Ruthless\", was played on a joint [[Instagram]] live stream.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Jay Critch Goes Live In The Studio With Lil Tjay

19th-century German pianist and composer: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and his songs \"Brothers\" and \"Leaked\", which became staples on the [[SoundCloud]] charts and led to his signing with [[Columbia Records]].

19th-century German pianist and composer: Mobile app designed to aid contact tracing}}

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: '''COVID-19 apps''' are [[mobile app]]s designed to aid [[contact tracing]] with the intention of suppressing the infectious disease [[Coronavirus disease 2019]]. On 10 April 2020, the market leaders in mobile devices, [[Google]] and [[Apple, Inc.
19th-century German pianist and composer: Apple]], jointly announced that they would integrate functionality to support such apps directly into their [[Android (operating system)

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The Chinese government, in conjunction with [[Alipay]], has deployed an app across 200 Chinese cities.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=China's coronavirus detection app is reportedly sharing citizen data with police

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In South Korea, the [[Corona 100m]] app has been developed to notify people of nearby cases.<ref>{{Cite news
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=South Korea took rapid, intrusive measures against Covid-19 – and they worked

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In Singapore, an app called [[TraceTogether]] is being used.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=Use of surveillance to fight coronavirus raises concerns about government power after pandemic ends

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Russia has introduced a tracking app for patients diagnosed with COVID-19 living in Moscow, designed to ensure they do not leave home.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Moscow coronavirus app raises privacy concerns

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Czechia has launched a Singapore-inspired tracking app called eRouška (eFacemask). The app was developed by local IT community, released as open source and will be handed over to the government.<ref name=\"czechcrunch1\">{{cite web
column3: title=V Česku se spouští aplikace eRouška. Staví na ochraně soukromí a upozorní, pokud jste přišli do kontaktu s nakaženým - CzechCrunch

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: North Macedonia launched the Bluetooth-based app „StopKorona!“ to  trace exposure with potentially infected persons and  provide a fast response to healthcare authorities. The app was developed and donated by a Macedonian IT company. <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=StopKorona! – tracing of Coronavirus exposure and protection from COVID-19

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In the United Kingdom, [[Matthew Gould]], chief executive of [[NHSX]], the government body responsible for policy regarding technology in the [[NHS]], said in late March 2020 that the organisation was looking seriously at an app that would alert people if they had recently been in contact with someone testing positive for the virus after scientists advising the government suggested it \"could play a critical role\" in limiting lockdowns.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=UK considers virus-tracing app to ease lockdown

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A similar app is planned in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=HSE announces coronavirus contact-tracing app, but privacy concerns remain

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Privacy campaigners have voiced their concern regarding the implications of mass surveillance using coronavirus apps, in particular about whether surveillance infrastructure created to deal with the coronavirus pandemic will be dismantled once the threat has passed.<ref>{{cite news
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=The coronavirus is expanding the surveillance state. How will this play out?
column13: archive-date=}}</ref>  [[Amnesty International]] and over 100 other organizations issued a statement calling for limits on this kind of surveillance.<ref name=\":2\">{{cite web
column15: title=Behind the global efforts to make a privacy-first coronavirus tracking app
column26: access-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> The German [[Chaos Computer Club]] (CCC)<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=10 Prüfsteine für die Beurteilung von „Contact Tracing“-Apps
column38: archive-date=2020-04-11}}</ref> and [[Reporters Without Borders]] ({{lang
column41: title=Corona-App in Deutschland - Anonymität und Quellenschutz gewährleisten

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Some countries are using network-based location tracking instead of apps, eliminating both the need to download an app and the ability to avoid tracking. In Israel, network-based tracking has been approved.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Israel to track mobile phones of suspected coronavirus cases
column10: access-date=2020-04-01}}</ref> However, network-based solutions have significant potential privacy problems.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=ACLU White Paper: The Limits of Location Tracking in an Epidemic

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: As of 7 April 2020, over a dozen expert groups were working on privacy-friendly solutions, such as using [[Bluetooth Low Energy]] (BLE) to log a user's proximity to other cellphones.<ref name=\":2\"/> Users then receive a message if they've been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.<ref name=\":2\"/>

A group of European researchers, including from the [[Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute]] and [[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]], are under the umbrella of the [[Pan-European Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing]] (PEPP-PT) project,<ref>{{cite web
column4: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> developing a BLE-based app to serve this purpose that is designed to avoid the need for intrusive surveillance by the state.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Europe shares code for new coronavirus warning app
column17: title=In Germany, High Hopes For New COVID-19 Contact Tracing App That Protects Privacy
column28: title=An EU coalition of techies is backing a ‘privacy-preserving’ standard for COVID-19 contacts tracing
column37: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> However, PEPP-PT is a co-ordination effort which contains both centralised and decentralised approaches, and is not a single protocol.<ref>{{cite web
column38: author=DP-3T

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Decentralised protocols include [[Decentralized Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing]] (DP-PPT/DP-3T),<ref name=\"Lomas_20200406\">{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=EU privacy experts push a decentralized approach to COVID-19 contacts tracing
column14: title=documents/DP3T White Paper.pdf at master · DP-3T/documents · GitHub
column17: accessdate=2020-04-13}}</ref> [[Contact Event Numbers]] (CEN), [[Privacy Sensitive Protocols And Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing]] (PACT)<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=PACT: Privacy Sensitive Protocols And Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing
column38: author-last10=Sunshine
column47: archive-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> and others. In these protocols, identifiable personal data never leaves the device, and all matching happens on-device.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The Privacy Group at [[MIT Media Lab]] has been developing SafePaths,<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=2020-04-09}}</ref> a platform for using privacy-preserving techniques when collecting and using location or path intersection data to track the spread of COVID-19. It is based on research from the whitepaper \"Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic\" released in March 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Centralised protocols, where a central server must be trusted with all or part of a social graph, are prevalent, such as Singapore's TraceTogether.<ref>{{cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> Countries including Germany are reportedly preparing centralised protocols, although these have not yet been released.<ref name=\"Lomas_20200406\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: On 10 April 2020, the market leaders in mobile devices, [[Google]] and [[Apple, Inc.
19th-century German pianist and composer: Apple]], jointly announced an initiative for privacy-preserving contact tracing based on BLE technology and [[cryptography]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Apple and Google are launching a joint COVID-19 tracing tool for iOS and Android
column8: title=Apple and Google are building coronavirus tracking tech into iOS and Android – The two companies are working together, representing most of the phones used around the world.
column19: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> They also published specifications of the core technologies used in the system.<ref>{{cite web
column38: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: '''COVID-19 apps''' are [[mobile app]]s designed to aid [[contact tracing]] with the intention of suppressing the infectious disease [[Coronavirus disease 2019]]. On 10 April 2020, the market leaders in mobile devices, [[Google]] and [[Apple, Inc.
19th-century German pianist and composer: Apple]], jointly announced that they would integrate functionality to support such apps directly into their [[Android (operating system)

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The Chinese government, in conjunction with [[Alipay]], has deployed an app across 200 Chinese cities.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=China's coronavirus detection app is reportedly sharing citizen data with police

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In South Korea, the [[Corona 100m]] app has been developed to notify people of nearby cases.<ref>{{Cite news
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=South Korea took rapid, intrusive measures against Covid-19 – and they worked

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In Singapore, an app called [[TraceTogether]] is being used.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=Use of surveillance to fight coronavirus raises concerns about government power after pandemic ends

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Russia has introduced a tracking app for patients diagnosed with COVID-19 living in Moscow, designed to ensure they do not leave home.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Moscow coronavirus app raises privacy concerns

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Czechia has launched a Singapore-inspired tracking app called eRouška (eFacemask). The app was developed by local IT community, released as open source and will be handed over to the government.<ref name=\"czechcrunch1\">{{cite web
column3: title=V Česku se spouští aplikace eRouška. Staví na ochraně soukromí a upozorní, pokud jste přišli do kontaktu s nakaženým - CzechCrunch

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: North Macedonia launched the Bluetooth based app „StopKorona!“ to  trace exposure with potentially infected persons and  provide a fast response to healthcare authorities. The app was developed and donated by a Macedonian IT company. <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=StopKorona! – tracing of Coronavirus exposure and protection from COVID-19

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: In the United Kingdom, [[Matthew Gould]], chief executive of [[NHSX]], the government body responsible for policy regarding technology in the [[NHS]], said in late March 2020 that the organisation was looking seriously at an app that would alert people if they had recently been in contact with someone testing positive for the virus after scientists advising the government suggested it \"could play a critical role\" in limiting lockdowns.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=UK considers virus-tracing app to ease lockdown

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: A similar app is planned in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=HSE announces coronavirus contact-tracing app, but privacy concerns remain

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Privacy campaigners have voiced their concern regarding the implications of mass surveillance using coronavirus apps, in particular about whether surveillance infrastructure created to deal with the coronavirus pandemic will be dismantled once the threat has passed.<ref>{{cite news
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=The coronavirus is expanding the surveillance state. How will this play out?
column13: archive-date=}}</ref>  [[Amnesty International]] and over 100 other organizations issued a statement calling for limits on this kind of surveillance.<ref name=\":2\">{{cite web
column15: title=Behind the global efforts to make a privacy-first coronavirus tracking app
column26: access-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> The German [[Chaos Computer Club]] (CCC)<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=10 Prüfsteine für die Beurteilung von „Contact Tracing“-Apps
column38: archive-date=2020-04-11}}</ref> and [[Reporters Without Borders]] ({{lang
column41: title=Corona-App in Deutschland - Anonymität und Quellenschutz gewährleisten

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Some countries are using network-based location tracking instead of apps, eliminating both the need to download an app and the ability to avoid tracking. In Israel, network-based tracking has been approved.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Israel to track mobile phones of suspected coronavirus cases
column10: access-date=2020-04-01}}</ref> However, network-based solutions have significant potential privacy problems.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=ACLU White Paper: The Limits of Location Tracking in an Epidemic

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: As of 7 April 2020, over a dozen expert groups were working on privacy-friendly solutions, such as using [[Bluetooth Low Energy]] (BLE) to log a user's proximity to other cellphones.<ref name=\":2\"/> Users then receive a message if they've been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.<ref name=\":2\"/>

A group of European researchers, including from the [[Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute]] and [[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]], are under the umbrella of the [[Pan-European Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing]] (PEPP-PT) project,<ref>{{cite web
column4: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> developing a BLE-based app to serve this purpose that is designed to avoid the need for intrusive surveillance by the state.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Europe shares code for new coronavirus warning app
column17: title=In Germany, High Hopes For New COVID-19 Contact Tracing App That Protects Privacy
column28: title=An EU coalition of techies is backing a ‘privacy-preserving’ standard for COVID-19 contacts tracing
column37: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> However, PEPP-PT is a co-ordination effort which contains both centralised and decentralised approaches, and is not a single protocol.<ref>{{cite web
column38: author=DP-3T

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Decentralised protocols include [[Decentralized Privacy-Preserving Proximity Tracing]] (DP-PPT/DP-3T),<ref name=\"Lomas_20200406\">{{cite web
19th-century German pianist and composer: title=EU privacy experts push a decentralized approach to COVID-19 contacts tracing
column14: title=documents/DP3T White Paper.pdf at master · DP-3T/documents · GitHub
column17: accessdate=2020-04-13}}</ref> [[Contact Event Numbers]] (CEN), [[Privacy Sensitive Protocols And Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing]] (PACT)<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=PACT: Privacy Sensitive Protocols And Mechanisms for Mobile Contact Tracing
column38: author-last10=Sunshine
column47: archive-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> and others. In these protocols, identifiable personal data never leaves the device, and all matching happens on-device.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The Privacy Group at [[MIT Media Lab]] has been developing SafePaths,<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=2020-04-09}}</ref> a platform for using privacy-preserving techniques when collecting and using location or path intersection data to track the spread of COVID-19. It is based on research from the whitepaper \"Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic\" released in March 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Apps Gone Rogue: Maintaining Personal Privacy in an Epidemic

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Centralised protocols, where a central server must be trusted with all or part of a social graph, are prevalent, such as Singapore's TraceTogether.<ref>{{cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> Countries including Germany are reportedly preparing centralised protocols, although these have not yet been released.<ref name=\"Lomas_20200406\"/>

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: On 10 April 2020, the market leaders in mobile devices, [[Google]] and [[Apple, Inc.
19th-century German pianist and composer: Apple]], jointly announced an initiative for privacy-preserving contact tracing based on BLE technology and [[cryptography]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Apple and Google are launching a joint COVID-19 tracing tool for iOS and Android
column8: title=Apple and Google are building coronavirus tracking tech into iOS and Android – The two companies are working together, representing most of the phones used around the world.
column19: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref> They also published specifications of the core technologies used in the system.<ref>{{cite web
column38: archive-date=2020-04-10}}</ref>

column3: title=Apple and Google partner on COVID-19 contact tracing technology
column9: title=Apple and Google partner on COVID-19 contact tracing technology

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: '''Kaleo''' (stylized as '''KALEO''') is an Icelandic rock band that formed at [[Mosfellsbær]] in 2012, consisting of lead vocalist and guitarist JJ Julius Son, drummer David Antonsson, bassist Daniel Kristjansson, and lead guitarist Rubin Pollock. They have released two studio albums, ''Kaleo'' (2013) and ''[[A/B (album)
19th-century German pianist and composer: A/B]]'' (2016), as well as an EP, ''Glasshouse'' (2013). ''A/B'' has sold over one million albums worldwide. One of the singles from ''A/B'', \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", was certified double platinum in the US<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> and reached number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column3: Billboard]]'' [[Alternative Songs]] chart on 20 August 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Kaleo Earns First Alternative Songs No. 1 with 'Way Down We Go'
column7: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> Kaleo received a Grammy nomination in 2017 for Best Rock Performance for the song \"No Good\".<ref>{{cite web

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Julius Son is currently working on the follow-up to ''A/B'', titled ''Surface Sounds'' scheduled to be released on 5 June 2020 on Elektra. Lead singles \"I Want More\" and \"Break My Baby\" were released on 15 January 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=KALEO Returns With \"I Want More\" and \"Break My Baby\"
column5: accessdate=15 January 2020}}</ref> The band's song \"Alter Ego\" was released on 13 March 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=KALEO Announces New Album Surface Sounds Arriving 6/5

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Best friends since attending elementary school outside of Reykjavik, bandleader JJ Julius Son, drummer David Antonsson, and bassist Daniel Kristjansson began playing together at the age of 17 before adding guitarist Rubin Pollock to the mix in 2012. They named the band Kaleo, which means \"the sound\" in Hawaiian, and started their career with a handful of well-received shows at the 2012 Iceland Airwaves music festival, which was the band's first major public appearance.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web

Kaleo gained fame after covering the song \"Vor í Vaglaskógi\" which received heavy rotation on Icelandic state broadcaster [[RÚV]]'s radio station [[Rás 2]] and was featured on the station's top 10 list.<ref>{{cite web
column10: publisher=}}</ref> This song is also featured in the first episode of the TV series ''[[Trapped (Icelandic TV series)
column11: Trapped]]''. By year's end, Kaleo had signed with Sena, the country's main record label. Their self-titled debut went gold in their home country, spawning five number one hits and inspiring their first European tour.<ref>{{cite web

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: ===2013–present: Major label record deal, departure to America, ''A/B'' and touring===
In 2014, the band gained further attention with their single \"All the Pretty Girls\", which garnered over 87 million streams on [[Spotify]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: publisher=}}</ref> In early 2015, they signed with [[Atlantic Records]]<ref>{{cite web
column8: website=Atlantic Records Official Website}}</ref> and subsequently relocated to [[Austin, Texas]].<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Band Puts Down American Roots in Austin}}{{dead link
column13: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Throughout 2015, Kaleo received increasing attention in the United States. The band's [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW) debut in 2015 garnered press from ''[[Esquire (magazine)
column14: Esquire]]''{{'}}s \"40 Bands You Need to Hear\"<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=SXSW Preview: 40 Bands You Need to Hear
column27: website=Esquire}}</ref> as well as [[NPR]]'s \"The Austin 100: SXSW 2015 Feature and All Songs Considered SXSW 2015 Music Preview\". \"All the Pretty Girls\" peaked at number 9 on Billboard's [[Adult Alternative Songs]] chart.<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=Alternative Music: Top Alternative Songs Chart

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Another three singles were released to promote their upcoming major label debut album ''[[A/B (album)
19th-century German pianist and composer: A/B]]'': \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", \"No Good\", and \"I Can't Go On Without You\". The single \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", was released on August 2015 and gained critical acclaim. The single was certified gold in the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, South Africa and Germany, Platinum in Russia, Australia and the United States, and triple platinum in Canada. The single \"No Good\" was released shortly after and was featured in the promo for HBO's ''Vinyl''.<ref>{{cite web
column5: website=The Music Enthusiast - Dallas Music Blog
column6: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> The fourth single, \"I Can't Go On Without You\", was released on 18 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=WORLD PREMIERE: Kaleo \"I Can't Go On Without You\"
column11: via=teamcoco.com}}</ref> The album was released worldwide later that year on 10 June 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Announcing our debut album A/B - KALEO Official Blog

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The album peaked at number 16 on the [[Billboard 200
column6: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> and the band embarked on a tour, the Handprint Tour,<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Kaleo Schedules Show At Fonda Theatre
column10: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> in order to promote it. The tour began on 11 September 2016 and concluded on 30 November 2016. The band embarked on a second tour, the fall Express Tour,<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=KALEO Express Fall 2017 Tour Announcement - KALEO Official Blog
column14: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> which started on 25 August 2017 in [[Anaheim, California
column15: Anaheim]], California and ended on 25 November in [[Moscow]], Russia.

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Kaleo's music genre mainly focuses on [[Indie Music
column3: Alternative]] Rock music with elements of [[Folk music
column5: Blues Rock]]. The Icelandic folk music has inspired Kaleo. In an interview with [[Rolling Stone]], The band Frontman JJ Julius Son explained \"Growing up I was listening to a lot of American music and Blues artists and such and that was what kind of connected us.\".<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jtu-GM_xp1I</ref><ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Watch Kaleo Talk 'Vinyl' Spot, American Blues
column12: date=29 June 2016}}</ref> Their blues influences are mainly drawn from [[delta blues
column13: Delta Blues]] which was the target for some of the heavier songs in their album ''A/B''. Their music prominently features a distinctive [[resonator guitar

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: The group has made multiple appearances on [[Late night television in the United States
19th-century German pianist and composer: late night television]] shows including ''[[Conan (talk show)
column8: title=Kaleo Rock 'Way Down We Go' + 'No Good' on 'Jimmy Kimmel Live'
column11: website=Loudwire}}</ref> ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'' and [[The Late Show With Stephen Colbert]].<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=.@officialkaleo stood in solidarity with the LGBTQ community on #LNSM. @nycpride
column18: reason=Is there a source to prove that?}} Their songs have been heard on many other television shows including ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]'', ''[[Blindspot (TV series)
column30: The Blacklist]], [[Bering Sea Gold]],'' and ''[[The Good Fight]]''. \"Way Down We Go\" was featured in a no7 Skincare ad in the UK<ref>{{Cite web
column32: title=Boots No7 Commercial Song by KALEO
column35: access-date=2 October 2018}}</ref> and in the second trailer for the film ''[[Logan (film)

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Kaleo's \"Automobile\" was featured in the film ''[[Logan (film)
column5: via=www.imdb.com}}</ref> while \"[[Way Down We Go]]\" was used in ''[[Collateral Beauty]]''.<ref>{{Cite web

simpler,safe,Francis Schonken,"{{short d: Several Kaleo songs including \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", \"Hot Blood\", \"No Good\", \"All the Pretty Girls\" and \"Glass House\" have been featured in ''[[FIFA 16]]'',<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Far Cry 5 Official Game Soundtracks, a playlist by Ubisoft Music | Ubiloud on Spotify

19th-century German pianist and composer: A/B]]'': \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", \"No Good\", and \"I Can't Go On Without You\". The single \"[[Way Down We Go]]\", was released on August 2015 and gained critical acclaim. The single was certified gold in the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, South Africa and Germany, Platinum in Russia, Australia and the United States, and triple platinum in Canada. The single \"No Good\" was released shortly after and was featured in the promo for HBO's ''Vinyl''.<ref>{{cite web
column5: website=The Music Enthusiast - Dallas Music Blog
column6: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> The fourth single, \"I Can't Go On Without You\", was released on 18 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web

column11: via=teamcoco.com}}</ref> The album was released worldwide later that year on 10 June 2016.<ref>{{cite web

column14: accessdate=2 June 2019}}</ref> which started on 25 August 2017 in [[Anaheim, California
column15: Anaheim]], California and ended on 25 November in [[Moscow]], Russia.
